headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Christie, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the M&T Bank Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the call over to Don MacLeo
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Christie, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the M&T Bank Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the call over to Don MacLeod, Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. MacLeod, you may begin.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christie, and good afternoon. I'd like to thank everyone for participating in M&T's Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call, both by telephone and through the webcast. If you have not read our earnings release that we issued earlier this m
componenttext: Thank you, Christie, and good afternoon. I'd like to thank everyone for participating in M&T's Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call, both by telephone and through the webcast. If you have not read our earnings release that we issued earlier this morning, you may access it along with the financial tables and schedules from our website at www.mtb.com and by clicking on the Investor Relations link. Also before we start, I'd like to mention that comments made during this call might contain forward-looking statements relating to the banking industry and to M&T Bank Corporation. M&T encourages participants to refer to our SEC filings, including those found on Forms 8-K, 10-K and 10-Q for a complete discussion of forward-looking statements. Now I would like to introduce our Chief Financial Officer, René Jones.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don, and welcome everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call today. Based on the feedback we've received from some of you, we've added the tables in the back section of the release, which presents five quarter trends for the income statement
componenttext: Thank you, Don, and welcome everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call today. Based on the feedback we've received from some of you, we've added the tables in the back section of the release, which presents five quarter trends for the income statement and the balance sheet. Hopefully, we've made your analysis a little easier. I know it's been a busy day for some of you so let's go through the highlights quickly and get to your questions.For the full year of 2009, diluted earnings per common share were $2.89 compared with $5.01 for 2008. Net income for 2009 was $380 million compared with $556 million in 2008. Included in our GAAP earnings for 2009 were after-tax merger-related expenses net of the gain from the Bradford acquisition of $36 million or $0.31 per common share. There are $2 million or $0.02 per share of merger-related expenses in 2008. Also included in GAAP earnings for the past year was after-tax expense from the amortization of intangible assets amounting to $39 million or $0.34 per common share. This compares with $41 million or $0.36 per share in 2008.Net operating income, which we believe helps investors understand the effect of acquisitions on our results, and which excludes the amortization of intangibles as well as merger-related items, was $455 million or $3.54 per common share for 2009 compared with $599 million or $5.39 per share in 2008. In accordance with the SEC guidelines, this morning's press release contains a tabular reconciliation of GAAP and non-GAAP results, including intangible assets and equity.Turning to the fourth quarter, diluted earnings per common share were $1.04 in the fourth quarter of 2009, improved from $0.97 earned in the third quarter of 2009. Net income for the recent quarter was $137 million, up from $128 million in the linked quarter. After-tax merger-related expenses in the quarter relating to both Provident and Bradford Bank acquisitions were $4 million or $0.03 per common share in the recent quarter. This compares with net after-tax merger-related benefits of $9 million or $0.08 per common share in the third quarter of 2009, which came as a result of our acquisition of Bradford Bank. We expect no further merger-related expenses from either of the two acquisitions.The amortization of core deposits and other intangible assets amounted to $0.09 per common share in the fourth quarter of 2009 and in the linked quarter. Diluted net operating earnings per common share, excluding the amortization of core deposits and other intangibles, as well as merger related items that I just mentioned were $1.16 per common share for the recent quarter, up 18% from $0.98 in the linked quarter. M&T's net operating income for the quarter was $151 million, an increase of 17% from $129 million in the linked quarter.Next, I'd like to cover a few highlights from the balance sheet and the income statement. Intangible equivalent net interest income was $565 million for the fourth quarter, an 8% annualized increase from $553 million in the linked quarter and an increase of 15% from $491 million in the fourth quarter of 2008. The net interest margin continued to expand during the fourth quarter, averaging 3.71%, up from 3.61% in the third quarter. Approximately four basis points of the margin expansion came from repricing on consumer time deposits. An additional four basis points came from a shift in our funding mix, with higher non-maturity savings and  commercial DDA balances replacing time deposits and wholesale borrowing. The remainder of the expansion came from lower rates on wholesale borrowing. Notable during the quarter was a rise in yields on commercial & industrial loans, up nine basis points compared with the third quarter. Looking forward, we expect further widening of the margin for 2010. As for the balance sheet, average loans for the fourth quarter declined approximately $200 million from $52.3 billion, in the third quarter to $52.1 billion. Compared with this year's third quarter, changes in average loans by category were as follows. Commercial & industrial loans declined by 8%. Average loans to auto dealers to finance new model and year inventory grew by an annualized 18% as compared with the third quarter of 2009, while remaining C&I loans balances declined an annualized 10%. The decline in this latter category was exacerbated by pay-downs, charge-offs in both the third and fourth quarters and a reduction in certain non-core customer exposures. Commercial real estate loans and residential real estate loans each grew by an annualized 2%, and consumer loans declined by an annualized 3%. This includes a 14% annualized decline of indirect auto loans, reflecting continued run-off in the out-of-footprint part of that portfolio. This was partially offset by a modest mid-single-digit growth in our home equity lines of credit.Recently, we experienced low single-digit annualized growth in upstate New York, while experiencing low to mid-single-digit decline in the New York City metro region and in Pennsylvania. The decline in commercial and industrial loans from pay downs, charge-offs and exits were concentrated in the mid-Atlantic. Excluding those items, loans in the mid-Atlantic were relatively flat. We continue to see strong growth in core deposits. Average core customer deposits in the fourth quarter, which excludes foreign deposits and CDs over $100,000, as well as excluding any acquisition impact, increased by an annualized 15% from the third quarter, with growth coming in every geographic region. Also notable is the fact that the average non-interest-bearing deposits in the fourth quarter of '09 were up 50% compared with the fourth quarter of 2008. This also excludes the impact from acquisitions.Turning to non-interest income, excluding securities gains and losses and the third quarter $29 million gain from the Bradford acquisition, non-interest income was $300 million for the recent quarter compared with $296 million in the third quarter. Mortgage banking fees were $50 million for the quarter, up from $48 million in the linked quarter. This reflects the impact of wider gain-on-sale margins, partially offset by slightly lower origination volume. Service charges on deposit accounts were $127 million during the quarter, compared with $129 million in the linked quarter. The decline came primarily on the commercial side and was largely attributable to fewer processing days in the fourth quarter compared with the third quarter.M&T's share of operating results of Bayview Lending Group or BLG was a loss of $11 million, unchanged from the linked quarter. BLG's recent performance was largely attributable to an increase in loan loss provisioning. Securities in the fourth quarter amounted to $34 million, predominantly reflecting an additional other-than-temporary impairment charges on our available-for-sale securities portfolio. This was down from $47 million of other-than-temporary impairment charges in the third quarter.Operating expenses were well-controlled during the recent quarter. Excluding merger-related expenses and the amortization of intangible assets, operating expenses were $455 million, down from $469 million in the third quarter of '09. The decline was primarily attributable to lower compensation expense, including core salaries, as well as incentive compensation. The fourth quarter's result included a $4 million reversal of a valuation allowance for capitalized residential mortgage servicing rights. This compares to no adjustments to the valuation allowance in the third quarter of '09 and a $19 million addition to the allowance in the fourth quarter of 2008. As of the end of 2009, we have reversed substantially all of the valuation allowance for capitalized residential mortgage servicing revenue. Excluding the benefit from the MSR, other operating expenses also declined slightly.The operating efficiency ratio, which excludes security gains and losses, as well as merger-related items and intangible amortization was 52.7% in the fourth quarter of 2009 compared with 55.2% in the linked quarter and 57% in the fourth quarter of 2008. The decline in efficiency ratio from the fourth quarter of 2008 is impressive, given that it reflects an $18 million increase in the FDIC assessment relative to the fourth quarter of 2008.Overall, credit -- let's turn to credit. Overall credit trends progressed as expected, with stable net charge-offs and a modest increase in non-performing assets. Non-accrual loans increased to $1.3 billion or 2.56% of loans at the end of the recent quarter, up $103 million from $1.2 billion or 2.35% of loans at the end of the previous quarter, an increase of about 8%. Substantially, all of the linked-quarter increase relates to a single commercial real estate loan for $104 million in Manhattan. This represents one of only two non-accrual loans of any significance in our greater New York City Metropolitan area. This particular loan is one I mentioned on the October earnings conference call and for which the recent appraisals indicate that the value of the property continues to be in excess of the loan balance. Despite the move to non-performing status, our outlook with regard to the resolution of this particular credit hasn't changed much. We continue to view the loss content as low and based on our original underwriting. Other non-performing assets, consisting of assets taken into foreclosure of defaulted loans, were $95 million as of December 31, compared with $85 million as of September 30.Net charge-offs for the fourth quarter were $135 million, down from $141 million in the third quarter of 2009. Annualized net charge-offs as a percentage of loans were 1.03%, improved from 1.07% in the linked quarter. Charge-offs for commercial and industrial loans were $31 million in the fourth quarter, down from $71 million in the linked quarter. Net charge-offs for residential builder construction loans were $40 million for the recent quarter, compared with $13 million in the prior quarter. For the full year of 2009, net charge-offs on residential construction credits totaled $92 million, down from $100 million in 2008. Net charge-offs for all other commercial real estate loans were $11 million, compared with $8 million in the third quarter. Net charge-offs on residential real estate loans were $21 million in the fourth quarter, up just $1 million from the linked quarter and net charge-offs on consumer loans was $32 million in the fourth quarter compared with $30 million in the linked quarter. The provision for credit losses was $145 million for the fourth quarter, compared with $154 million in the linked quarter. Provision exceeded net charge-offs by $10 million and increased the allowance of loan losses to $878 million as of the end of 2009. The ratio of allowance for credit losses to legacy M&T loans, which exclude acquired loans in which there's already a credit mark, was up 1.83%, up from 1.81% in the linked quarter. As of December 31, 2008, that ratio was 1.61%.For the full year 2009, charge-offs were $514 million or 1.01% of average loans. We believe this represents the lowest rate among large regional and super regional banks. The loan-loss allowance as of December 31, 2009, was 1.7 times net charge-offs for the past year.Loans past due 90 days are still accruing with $208 million at the end of the recent quarter and included $193 million of loans guaranteed by government-related entities. Those figures were $183 million and $173 million respectively at the end of the sequential quarter. M&T's tangible common equity ratio was 5.13% at the end of the fourth quarter, an increase of 24 basis points from 4.89% at the end of the quarter. Unrealized, pre-tax losses on our available-for-sale investment portfolio were $293 million at the end of the quarter, compared with $313 million at the end of the third quarter and $806 million at the end of 2008.Turning to our outlook, as most of you know, we don't offer much in the way of earnings guidance, but we'll share our thoughts on some general trends. While the economy appears to be stable, the pace of recovery is slow. As a result, we expect both loan and overall earnings [indiscernible] growth to be in the low single digits. With the current trends being slightly negative, we'll need to see a turnaround in the current trends by the middle of the year in order to be able to achieve that growth. The demand for credit from customers, whether to build inventories or to expand plant capacity just isn't there yet, and when combined with the portfolios that we have that are in run-off mode, like parts of our indirect auto and asset growth, should be relatively modest. The strong inflows of deposits, particularly on the commercial side, are also an indication that businesses aren't ready to increase investment. As I mentioned earlier, the outlook for interest margin is for additional widening, as two fundamental trends remain in effect. Turnover in the loan portfolio, that is to, say, repayments and renewals is pricing in the benefit from today's wider credit spread, and the continued inflows of non-interest-bearing deposits I just mentioned are also a positive. We'd expect less impact, going forward, from the favorable repricing of time deposits.While credit costs remain elevated as the current credit cycle continues to play out, our inflows of loans into non-accruals status and our loss experience continues to be very manageable. Over the past several quarters, it appears that the consumer and the residential real estate credit terms [ph] have stabilized, but they're not improving yet. Fortunately, our exposure to these portfolios is relatively modest. We had the lowest charge-off rate among large regional and super regional banks in this year's third quarter. And given our underwriting culture, our habit of addressing problem areas proactively and the trends we've seen in our criticized loan portfolio, we believe we'll continue to report strong relative performance in 2010. As you know, we've always placed a priority on operating efficiency and will continue to do so. That said, as we plan for the future, the area of most uncertainty is in the rising cost of regulation.Finally, I'll remind you that normalized for unusual items, the first quarter's results have attended to be seasonally low for us, reflecting fewer days and higher expenses associated with FICA, accelerated recognition of option expense or equity expense and the 401(k) match. Of course, all of these projections are subject to a number of uncertainties, various assumptions regarding national economic growth, changes in interest rates, political event and other macro-economic factors, which may differ materially from what actually unfolds in the future. We'll now open up the call to questions, before which Christie will briefly review the instructions.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Steven Alexopoulos with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Steven Alexopoulos with JPMorgan.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about -- are all the cost saves and revenue synergies from the two deals now on a run rate?
componenttext: Can you talk about -- are all the cost saves and revenue synergies from the two deals now on a run rate?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the answer is no. And the way you think about that is that when you think about the opportunities that we have on the distribution side, that just takes some time. So with seven months through the transaction, I would think that 2010, particularly
componenttext: I think the answer is no. And the way you think about that is that when you think about the opportunities that we have on the distribution side, that just takes some time. So with seven months through the transaction, I would think that 2010, particularly for our retail folks, we'll be continuing to sort of work through the distribution-type issues, which at the end of the day, will result in additional expense savings. I think we're more than halfway through the expense savings. In fact, I know we're well more than halfway through the expense savings. On the revenue side, I think that the same is true there. The idea of sort of optimizing the work you do on the revenue side, particularly with sort of offering all your services to the new customers, I think that takes a little time. So we would hope that there's continued opportunity through the year 2010 on that side, as well. It's harder to identify it on the revenue side.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Second question, looking at the $6 billion of commercial real estate loans in the New York City area, one, can you talk about what the renewal schedule looks like this year and maybe next year? And then second, are you seeing anything in terms of early-st
componenttext: Second question, looking at the $6 billion of commercial real estate loans in the New York City area, one, can you talk about what the renewal schedule looks like this year and maybe next year? And then second, are you seeing anything in terms of early-stage delinquencies there?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start I think your questions in the order. It's a tough question to answer because when you look at the renewals, if you think about what we do, it matters what year that they're coming from. So the thing that helps us most is that from, say,
componenttext: Well, let me start I think your questions in the order. It's a tough question to answer because when you look at the renewals, if you think about what we do, it matters what year that they're coming from. So the thing that helps us most is that from, say, 2004 through the third quarter of 2007, we kept our commercial real estate portfolio relatively flat. So maybe the numbers in December will fall at something like $5.1 billion. By the time we got to September of '07 we're at about $5.3 billion, somewhere in that range. We've put some stuff on in the fourth quarter of '07. So the average life of our portfolio, my guess would be somewhere around five years, but if you think about what's coming to renewal next year, a lot of it would be things that were de-booked as far as long ago as 10 years. What's good about that is that they're not booked in anywhere near the roughly [ph] times. And so you have much more equity component in there. If you go back to 2004, if you think of our portfolio as a five-year portfolio, it would give you kind of an average, let's say an average life of five years. You're basically saying we must have booked $1 billion a year to do that. I would say in 2004, for example, we booked half of that because we just couldn't figure out what was going on. So on the renewals that we'll see this year, I would guess that the most of them are coming from things that were booked way before 2004. And we're still doing our work on the schedules. I think at some point we're going to publish that maturity schedule, but the more we get into it, in order to sort of give you something that gives you a sense of our portfolio, just sort of takes us a little bit of time. So that's on that sense. In terms of the portfolio, as I said the last call, we had a couple of credits that we sort of have -- what I would call in our watch list. One of them came into non-performing this quarter. There hasn't been anything new that we've seen through our portfolio reviews. And our portfolio reviews are pretty granular. I think the thing to think about is that because we're so granular and focused on getting ahead of the problem, and because the lead time is long, my sense is that to the extent that we have additional credits that go into non-performing, you're going to sort of hear about them so much before they happen. So no real change, we haven't seen any sort of additional problem credits and delinquencies in the New York City portfolio. Last thing I'll say on this, if I could, is that reflecting back on 2009, actually you learn a lot. Right? So we have no losses in the portfolio in 2009. And we actually had nothing rolling to non-performing but for this last credit that we just took this quarter. So when you look back at that, really, one of the most significant factors is not that actual credit wasn't weakening in New York City, it was that most, if not all of our sponsors, were willing to step up because they saw real value in the properties, and they're willing to kick in additional resources if they were needed in order to keep the project moving forward. So when we look at '09 and we look at our sponsors behave and what the result was, we felt pretty good about sort of where we are today.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Just on Bayview, obviously, you've lost by $11 million or so this quarter. Do you mind just providing another update? Looks like we're kind of going on at about two years of consistent losses, I'm just wondering if anything has changed?
componenttext: Just on Bayview, obviously, you've lost by $11 million or so this quarter. Do you mind just providing another update? Looks like we're kind of going on at about two years of consistent losses, I'm just wondering if anything has changed?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: No, there's no change. Again, the largest share of our valuation is supported by residuals that are not included in what you're seeing on the income statement, and it's supported by their other businesses, namely, the Bayview Asset Management. So while --
componenttext: No, there's no change. Again, the largest share of our valuation is supported by residuals that are not included in what you're seeing on the income statement, and it's supported by their other businesses, namely, the Bayview Asset Management. So while -- I think the losses were maybe a little bit higher than I would've expected for the quarter, much of that has to do with really looking at the credit for the loans that were in BLG, the original BLG, and looking at the adequacy of the allowance there and the value of the asset. So no real change and I wouldn't expect to see a big change in the future either.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: The other question I just had was on the the net interest margin. I heard your comments that, obviously, the CD benefit or the repricing of the CDs should provide less of a benefit, going forward. There's going to be more makeshift, so to speak. I guess,
componenttext: The other question I just had was on the the net interest margin. I heard your comments that, obviously, the CD benefit or the repricing of the CDs should provide less of a benefit, going forward. There's going to be more makeshift, so to speak. I guess, from what I understand, the mix shift should have been a little more slowly or have a lesser impact, is that consistent with your view that if you got 10 basis points of improvement this quarter, maybe it's less than that, going forward, and -- or am I wrong in terms of that thinking?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I could have asked the question the same way. Yes, I think, first of all, you're right. The time deposit benefit, if I kind of go that overtime, the four basis points this quarter was less of the contribution that we see in the past quarter. But what is s
componenttext: I could have asked the question the same way. Yes, I think, first of all, you're right. The time deposit benefit, if I kind of go that overtime, the four basis points this quarter was less of the contribution that we see in the past quarter. But what is starting to happen now, and I kind of made that comment that while we didn't see the yield rise much on earnings assets, underlying, you do have this sort of trend where you're repricing your commercial loan book and even the rest of your book. And you saw on the C&I book that nine-basis-point rise in the yield, right? So I think what you're going to get is some shifting over to the asset side, where you're going to start to see some of that benefit from there. So that should that should pick up a little bit of the slack. And then I think that we've yet to see -- it's amazing -- we've yet to see that this trend in non-interest-bearing deposits keep growing. So my sense is that yes, you're probably right. I mean, if I were to guess again, I'd say, "Yes, it's going to slow." But going into the quarter, we didn't see much slowing. So my sense is it will be a little slower than we've seen on a quarter-to-quarter basis. Maybe we'll be somewhere -- I'd be surprised if we were above 3 85, 3 80 for the full year. I'd be surprised by that.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: More[ph]  increase in the Fed funds I assume?
componenttext: More[ph]  increase in the Fed funds I assume?

componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean that's the other issue. It's because we're asset-sensitive today, we've kind of positioned ourselves that if there is an increase in short-term rates, that's a positive to us today. So we kind of borrow that.
componenttext: Yes, I mean that's the other issue. It's because we're asset-sensitive today, we've kind of positioned ourselves that if there is an increase in short-term rates, that's a positive to us today. So we kind of borrow that.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: On the consumer side, the 30-plus delinquencies were 1.67%, up six basis points from the link quarter and up six basis points from a year ago. So not much of a change. That's the $10 billion portfolio. On the resi mortgages, there's almost no change when
componenttext: On the consumer side, the 30-plus delinquencies were 1.67%, up six basis points from the link quarter and up six basis points from a year ago. So not much of a change. That's the $10 billion portfolio. On the resi mortgages, there's almost no change when you look at the core and the Alt-A portfolio together. We just didn't see much change. I think the dollar amount actually may have come down a little bit, but the rate was flat. On the commercial side, what's interesting is that, we often get a lot of questions about our provisioning, our allowance, and the thing that you saw, this -- that you can't see even though the non-performers went up is that the classified loan book was down, probably, $200 million to $300 million underneath. So there was a bit of progress there. And I guess when you step back and look at that and do all the way back to mid-year. It means sort of the second half of the year, the rising pace of criticized or classified loans actually slowed dramatically, and it really wasn't much of an increase from June 30 to December 31. So all the trends are, I guess, from where we've been, positive right? But we also don't see a dramatic rebound in credit.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the -- if you gross up your prime loans, if you include the TDRs, for example, it looks like to that pace of the addition for collective and fairly consistent last three quarters, somewhere around $290 million a quarter. Just sounds like we've
componenttext: And then on the -- if you gross up your prime loans, if you include the TDRs, for example, it looks like to that pace of the addition for collective and fairly consistent last three quarters, somewhere around $290 million a quarter. Just sounds like we've got the $104 million tied to that Manhattan theory credit, but I'm just wondering if you could give us some additional granularity as to what else might have been added in the quarter.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: There wasn't a lot. Nothing of that magnitude, maybe handful of credits I'd say that were over $5 million. And then there were just a host of paydowns and payoffs and those types to offset it. But let me give you this, if you look at the book, C&I was --
componenttext: There wasn't a lot. Nothing of that magnitude, maybe handful of credits I'd say that were over $5 million. And then there were just a host of paydowns and payoffs and those types to offset it. But let me give you this, if you look at the book, C&I was -- the non-performing loans in C&I were down. Residential was down. Consumer loans were up $2 million. And the only increase was about -- real estate was $119 million, of which this was $104 million.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a risk of sort of characterizing other inflows in the non-performers. They were primarily residential construction credits.
componenttext: It's a risk of sort of characterizing other inflows in the non-performers. They were primarily residential construction credits.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: That's good. That's right. So anything besides -- on the real estate side, what you had was many of the sort of credits that we had previously identified on the residential side have sort of migrated through the process. There's nothing new so to speak.
componenttext: That's good. That's right. So anything besides -- on the real estate side, what you had was many of the sort of credits that we had previously identified on the residential side have sort of migrated through the process. There's nothing new so to speak.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of your coverage on annualized net charges, I know you guys have internally targeted at least on average two times. And last couple of quarters we tripped a little bit below, just curious whether or not you've changed your view on the loss conten
componenttext: In terms of your coverage on annualized net charges, I know you guys have internally targeted at least on average two times. And last couple of quarters we tripped a little bit below, just curious whether or not you've changed your view on the loss content maybe? Do you expect coming out of this cycle or if there's a change? And how you're managing that reserve?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: No, no. We're looking at it pretty closely. And when you look at the reserves to charge-offs, you see -- sort of see, but I think you described that pretty well. We feel pretty comfortable where we are. From what we can see, there's only one bank in the t
componenttext: No, no. We're looking at it pretty closely. And when you look at the reserves to charge-offs, you see -- sort of see, but I think you described that pretty well. We feel pretty comfortable where we are. From what we can see, there's only one bank in the top 20 or at least the larger regional --  super regionals that had a number of reserve that's high relative to the losses. So I think we feel pretty good about it. And we also have been looking at the trends in the classified loan book as well.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of capital, you're rapidly approaching what historically, you've targeted for TCE of, I guess, 5 2 to 5 6. Could you give us some updated thoughts just given sort of industry-wide higher capital levels, and maybe plans to repay TARP et cetera?
componenttext: In terms of capital, you're rapidly approaching what historically, you've targeted for TCE of, I guess, 5 2 to 5 6. Could you give us some updated thoughts just given sort of industry-wide higher capital levels, and maybe plans to repay TARP et cetera?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're sort of approaching our range. But my sense is that, we're not going to change anything with our distribution policies, and we'll just continue to build capital until there's some clarity as to what the expectations will be. But today, you have
componenttext: Yes, we're sort of approaching our range. But my sense is that, we're not going to change anything with our distribution policies, and we'll just continue to build capital until there's some clarity as to what the expectations will be. But today, you haven't heard much. So I would suggest that we'll just keep building capital and stay on the same page that we're at until we actually get some sort of tangible guidance on what the new capital rules will be, if there are any, and a little bit more clarity there. And the environment is not such that you would actually sort of change that, so my sense is that we'll keep building.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010

componenttext: And do you think you all will attempt to pay TARP in 2010?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our view is sort of wait and see, watch the environment. The economy hasn't turned yet. And we have the ability to do it. And to the extent that things improve and the economy turns around and it makes sense to do it, then maybe we will. But at this point
componenttext: Our view is sort of wait and see, watch the environment. The economy hasn't turned yet. And we have the ability to do it. And to the extent that things improve and the economy turns around and it makes sense to do it, then maybe we will. But at this point, we've made no determination to that.

componenttext: And then maybe just while you look for that number, as you think about provision for 2010, given the sort of promising trends and classified loans and new non-accruals your provision was down in the quarter, do you think that provision has peaked if things continue on the track their on economically?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I can't say yes or no. That's hard to say. The trends were nice to see, but relative normal times, the environment is still shaky. And if you happen to see a problem credit or two come up, then you got to provide for them. It would be too early to call a
componenttext: I can't say yes or no. That's hard to say. The trends were nice to see, but relative normal times, the environment is still shaky. And if you happen to see a problem credit or two come up, then you got to provide for them. It would be too early to call a peak. And I think maybe we'll all be calling the peak about three or four quarters after it happens.  And the answer to your other question, that about 566.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Siegenthaler with Credit Suisse.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: First, really just on the NIM guidance, can you talk about what levers MTB still has available to improve the NIM? And also, should we expect a similar sort of pickup in the first quarter the first half? And then maybe you could talk about how asset-sensi
componenttext: First, really just on the NIM guidance, can you talk about what levers MTB still has available to improve the NIM? And also, should we expect a similar sort of pickup in the first quarter the first half? And then maybe you could talk about how asset-sensitive you are relative to peers, especially if the Fed's raising rates in the second half?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we think, the second part first, our asset sensitivity -- we're asset-sensitive. And I think for a 200 basis point gradual increase, we've got something like a 2% positive. It's about 2% positive. But having said that, that all depends on what you e
componenttext: Well, we think, the second part first, our asset sensitivity -- we're asset-sensitive. And I think for a 200 basis point gradual increase, we've got something like a 2% positive. It's about 2% positive. But having said that, that all depends on what you end up doing with your deposit rates, right? And so the way I like to think about it is that, if we get to a situation where rates are rising, it will either result in a higher net interest margin or it gives us a lot of powder in terms of pricing deposits in doing what we want to do there, right? Because we can make that neutral pretty easily. So I like to kind of think of it as we're sort of well-positioned for deposit growth or for actually arising margins in that event. I talked about the net interest margin over time, I think the thing that's going to work well for banks like M&T that do a lot of plain vanilla banking is that as long as the securitization markets are shut down, it means credit spreads are wider. And it takes a long time for sort of that repricing to roll through our books based on the terms of the credit that we have on our book. So I think it -- a lot of it depends on how long the securitization markets in Wall Street remain quiet. And quite frankly, that's just not come back yet. And it tends to be a help to regional banks. Will it be 10 basis points a quarter? I find that hard to believe. But I don't have much more insight than that on the actual magnitude.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Renè, just a follow up to Ken's question on Bayview. We're just thinking about how it's been flowing in. Its been pretty steady, the last few quarters, but can you help us understand the duration is? And how many more quarters of losses we should expect?
componenttext: Renè, just a follow up to Ken's question on Bayview. We're just thinking about how it's been flowing in. Its been pretty steady, the last few quarters, but can you help us understand the duration is? And how many more quarters of losses we should expect? And is there a risk of  a spike in any given quarter depending on the frequency of delinquencies in the portfolio?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I kinda answered this before. I would expect, on an ongoing basis, for that originations franchise based on how it's operating not originating many loans, that it's going to operate at a slight loss. And maybe that's a $5 million somewhere in that r
componenttext: Well, I kinda answered this before. I would expect, on an ongoing basis, for that originations franchise based on how it's operating not originating many loans, that it's going to operate at a slight loss. And maybe that's a $5 million somewhere in that range a quarter. I wouldn't be surprised by that at all. Is there a risk that you could get some kind of event that says particularly like the value of the residuals has changed? Sure, but we would talk about that when we saw and where we saw it. I think the basis of Bayview is now $246 million. So relative to sort of our earnings power and those types of things, I don't look at it with much different as any other sort of loan relationships that we have. But if there was new news, we'd tell you about it. We haven't had any new news yet.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Heather Wolf with UBS.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Just one quick question on the securities losses, can you give us a little bit more color on where those are coming from? I'm assuming it's from the high-burn arm book [ph]? And also in where we are, and how much further we have to go in those write-downs
componenttext: Just one quick question on the securities losses, can you give us a little bit more color on where those are coming from? I'm assuming it's from the high-burn arm book [ph]? And also in where we are, and how much further we have to go in those write-downs?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: So maybe $29 million or so were from the private label mortgage-backed securities that same portfolio. And then there were some small other items. The remainder of CDO, I think that we had wrote down in 2007, maybe $2 million there on another small securi
componenttext: So maybe $29 million or so were from the private label mortgage-backed securities that same portfolio. And then there were some small other items. The remainder of CDO, I think that we had wrote down in 2007, maybe $2 million there on another small security, so mostly private label mortgage-backed securities. The process is not different from what we've been going through. What you need to be able to see is, remember we've taken about $148 million of losses on that portfolio in terms of -- we've written down $148 million. But the actual losses that we'd experienced, breaks in the bonds is about $7 million. And what we're doing every quarter is we're projecting out when the mortgage and how the market is going to turn and what the delinquencies are likely to be. And because we haven't seen any change, really, in those trends, as time goes by, if you don't see a change, there's a probability that in the future you may have more losses, right? Most of the lessons, as I've said before, Heather, have come from, as we disclosed in the queues, the subordinated notes. So of the total $1.2 billion that we have of private label mortgage-backed securities that didn't get originated by M&T, this portfolio we're talking about, of the most subordinated parts of the structures, there's about $100 million left. And there's about $1.7 billion or $1.8 billion of which our SMO senior ends, which we feel very good about. So as we kind of look at 2008, we could see more charges if we don't see a turnaround in the housing market. Overall, though I wouldn't expect them to be anything larger than we might have seen to date.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010

componenttext: I just have a follow-up on the securities. The AOCI is obviously been approving throughout the year and helping the ratios. And I'm just curious do you expect to see that to continue to some of these mortgage-backs? I assume they're amortizing. you're getting power back. So can you just talk about the outlook for the mark and for amortization of the securities for 2010?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean it depends on what happens with the interest rates. We talk about private label mortgage-backed securities a lot but most of what we have is agency. And so all of that is just sort of subject to the change in rate. When you go from December 31
componenttext: Yes, I mean it depends on what happens with the interest rates. We talk about private label mortgage-backed securities a lot but most of what we have is agency. And so all of that is just sort of subject to the change in rate. When you go from December 31 of '08 to now, you spend just a dramatic improvement in the pricing of the private label mortgage-backed securities. And you know when you should talk to your capital markets groups and that sort of has continued at a fairly steady pace. But it's too hard to tell. Obviously, were out of the lows, but it's hard to predict where that's going to go. So when we think about capital planning, we don't assume that there'll be any change.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: No negative news. I think if you look at where we were  -- so that was 13 months ago that we did that due diligence work. And right now, our losses are really tracking nowhere near what we would have estimated. So having said that, I think the thing that
componenttext: No negative news. I think if you look at where we were  -- so that was 13 months ago that we did that due diligence work. And right now, our losses are really tracking nowhere near what we would have estimated. So having said that, I think the thing that you should look to is when we're really confident in that, we would actually say something, because it's a little too early. We've had the portfolio for about seven months. But no problems, things have, for the first seven months what we expected. They're much better than what we thought. But we've yet to sort of declare victory there. And I think we're going to wait for another year to sort of see what happens before we think about monetizing that in any way.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: On a macro level, I think there needs to be much more certainty out there with the regulatory environment, the economic environment for people to start drawing down on their line and to start making investments. And so as we kind of look out for our plann
componenttext: On a macro level, I think there needs to be much more certainty out there with the regulatory environment, the economic environment for people to start drawing down on their line and to start making investments. And so as we kind of look out for our planning purposes for 2010, my sense is that the current trends are what you're going to see for the first half. And we sort of had this thought that it's possible that we'll begin to see more utilization as we get to the second half of the year. Something like that. Remember, there's a bit of a natural hedge going on here, because if that doesn't happen, we won't have the loan growth. But I would bet you, we still have a lot of deposit growth.

componenttext: I guess what I'd say this quarter is we just look at all [ph] the pretty standard consistent process. I think that we've started to show on a quarterly basis our allowance along with our, as they go to each of our loan portfolios, and as we broken our allowance in that Q, or at least we did that at the year-end. You'll see that we're putting aside allowance is probably the areas that would make more sense to do so. So you'll see higher allowance in the real estate portfolios and maybe steady allowances in other places. So our thought process was not different than any other quarter that we've seen. And if you go back to the first quarter of last year, we added $58 million of excess, we saw some problem, right? So we didn't much knew.

componenttext: Could you give us some guidance on your tax rate going forward? And then secondly, I have a question. Could you give a little bit more color on the new non-accrual loan, the $100 million CRE loan in Manhattan? Anything you can give detail wise.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: On the tax rate, I don't know that there was anything -- that's a tough one for the full year, so I get why you're asking that. Let me think about it, then I'll come back to that. The loan that we took to non-accrual this year, if you go back to what we d
componenttext: On the tax rate, I don't know that there was anything -- that's a tough one for the full year, so I get why you're asking that. Let me think about it, then I'll come back to that. The loan that we took to non-accrual this year, if you go back to what we did, it's a loan that we booked in 2007, so December of 2007. And we booked it as a bridge loan. And if you remember -- so we hadn't done much when the capital markets sort of shut down, the CMBS market has been shut down ever since. At that point in time, we saw a lot of folks coming to us with different credits. This is one of the ones that we did. And I think it's probably a pretty good case of sort of the culture of M&T. We actually booked that loan at a loan-to-value of between 43% to 50%. The range is dependent upon whether you want to do it just on the face value of the loan or on the cost to maintain it and improve it and get it ready for use over time, right? So when you look at it, we booked that loan of $100 million, we had more than $100 million of ownership equity in front of us in terms of loss content, right? So you hear a lot about commercial real estate being down by large percentages in New York City. Most of those are quoting things that are off of the 2007 high in terms of rent. But for us, we tend not to focus on sort of market value of current rent and we focus on pure historical value, in this case, it's the Class B space. And we intended to underwrite it relatively conservatively. So here we had an event where we're taking non-performing but because of the way we structured the deal, in our minds, the loss content is low, if any.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well I mean, I think while Washington, D.C, relative to other places, is pretty strong economically, I do think that Maryland, relative to New York State, Upstate New York, there's a difference there. So there's still a lot of help up here in Upstate New
componenttext: Well I mean, I think while Washington, D.C, relative to other places, is pretty strong economically, I do think that Maryland, relative to New York State, Upstate New York, there's a difference there. So there's still a lot of help up here in Upstate New York and we never saw the sort of big problems here. So you got a firm and a healthy company. So having said that, the biggest issue is simply that when you look at places where we need to pay down credit or we sort of exited credits or had a couple of larger charge-offs, particularly the C&I, the one that we mentioned last quarter for $40 million, they were just concentrated in those portfolios. And so what you're getting is much more about payoffs. And then finally, much more lower utilization, right? Where people are just not making as much in the way of investments. If you were to look at commitments, we'll continue to book new commitments and we're growing. But people are just not drawing down on them. So I would say that there's probably not that much of a difference in the two portfolios. And I would say if you were to look at it on raw commitments, that my guess would be that we are actually probably doing more new raw commitments in the Maryland area.

componenttext: Over time, it's been both. I mean, over the course of 2009, we picked up a lot of new relationships. But we also have seen that with the low-rate environment, it's beneficial to people to pay for their cash management services with balances.

componenttextpreview: No, we have to give -- in some of these trends, I mean, I think that there are certain things that have been improving. I think in some cases, there's a willingness for financial buyers to come in and put in equity into these companies, right? Because the
componenttext: No, we have to give -- in some of these trends, I mean, I think that there are certain things that have been improving. I think in some cases, there's a willingness for financial buyers to come in and put in equity into these companies, right? Because their prices have been very depressed and so as long as you actually get new buyers coming in or people willing to actually put in new equity and help the companies out, you're going to start to get some improving credits. So I think if there was a trend, there's probably more activity across almost every portfolio. We see it in the residential builder construction, it showed just more people willing to put money to work, and those people are investors basically.

componenttextpreview: Compare it, I mean I guess you sort of gave us the idea that in our minds for the first six to 12 months, we would expect that after an acquisition, we're going to see some run-off in deposits. And I would say that we've seen some of that with the Provide
componenttext: Compare it, I mean I guess you sort of gave us the idea that in our minds for the first six to 12 months, we would expect that after an acquisition, we're going to see some run-off in deposits. And I would say that we've seen some of that with the Provident acquisition. But most of it's on very high rate time and single-service customers. So nothing out of the ordinary beyond what we would've expected to see. Bradford, I actually don't. Yes, Bradford, there's some run-off. But most of it is in the all-set time [ph]. So I think it actually had growth in DDA, DDA now have been combined relatively stable, and the time deposit is running off. So there's no unusual trend there.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned that competition today is better because securitization is shut down. I'm trying to get some color on when securitization thus start back up again. What does M&T look like? How does competition compare versus when it was a big element? Have
componenttext: You mentioned that competition today is better because securitization is shut down. I'm trying to get some color on when securitization thus start back up again. What does M&T look like? How does competition compare versus when it was a big element? Have you picked up enough market share at this point where it's not a big deal? I know it's really forward looking, but if you could sort of give some color on that.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: One, I think it takes time. Two, I think we would welcome things that could be done that would provide confidence back into the market because I think it's good for everybody overall. And I think -- remember, if you go back two years ago or three years ag
componenttext: One, I think it takes time. Two, I think we would welcome things that could be done that would provide confidence back into the market because I think it's good for everybody overall. And I think -- remember, if you go back two years ago or three years ago now, maybe 2005 and 2006, people were saying, "You don't have much revenue growth." Well the issue there was everybody was lending and money was relatively cheap and so you couldn't get much growth. Now we're at the opposite end of the spectrum, and I think there's probably a lot of ground in the middle. And I think that for regional banks, it will be somewhat of a favorable environment relative to competition for some time. And the longer that we don't see much in the way of reform on the regulatory side, I think the longer we'll see the securitization markets and those types of things, people have some weariness about [ph]. But it's hard to tell, these things take a long time to change.

componenttext: I'm still saving our progress that we made this quarter. I don't know, I think we said before low 50s is something that we think that M&T from the past [ph] can do. And I think we'll continue to work our way there because at the end of the day, I think that's what's going to make a difference in your ability to be competitive. Low 50s.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christie, and good afternoon. I'd like to thank everyone for participating in M&T's Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call, both by telephone and through the webcast. If you have not read our earnings release that we issued earlier this m
componenttext: Thank you, Christie, and good afternoon. I'd like to thank everyone for participating in M&T's Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call, both by telephone and through the webcast. If you have not read our earnings release that we issued earlier this morning, you may access it along with the financial tables and schedules from our website at www.mtb.com and by clicking on the Investor Relations link. Also before we start, I'd like to mention that comments made during this call might contain forward-looking statements relating to the banking industry and to M&T Bank Corporation. M&T encourages participants to refer to our SEC filings, including those found on Forms 8-K, 10-K and 10-Q for a complete discussion of forward-looking statements. Now I would like to introduce our Chief Financial Officer, René Jones.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don, and welcome everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call today. Based on the feedback we've received from some of you, we've added the tables in the back section of the release, which presents five quarter trends for the income statement
componenttext: Thank you, Don, and welcome everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call today. Based on the feedback we've received from some of you, we've added the tables in the back section of the release, which presents five quarter trends for the income statement and the balance sheet. Hopefully, we've made your analysis a little easier. I know it's been a busy day for some of you so let's go through the highlights quickly and get to your questions.For the full year of 2009, diluted earnings per common share were $2.89 compared with $5.01 for 2008. Net income for 2009 was $380 million compared with $556 million in 2008. Included in our GAAP earnings for 2009 were after-tax merger-related expenses net of the gain from the Bradford acquisition of $36 million or $0.31 per common share. There are $2 million or $0.02 per share of merger-related expenses in 2008. Also included in GAAP earnings for the past year was after-tax expense from the amortization of intangible assets amounting to $39 million or $0.34 per common share. This compares with $41 million or $0.36 per share in 2008.Net operating income, which we believe helps investors understand the effect of acquisitions on our results, and which excludes the amortization of intangibles as well as merger-related items, was $455 million or $3.54 per common share for 2009 compared with $599 million or $5.39 per share in 2008. In accordance with the SEC guidelines, this morning's press release contains a tabular reconciliation of GAAP and non-GAAP results, including intangible assets and equity.Turning to the fourth quarter, diluted earnings per common share were $1.04 in the fourth quarter of 2009, improved from $0.97 earned in the third quarter of 2009. Net income for the recent quarter was $137 million, up from $128 million in the linked quarter. After-tax merger-related expenses in the quarter relating to both Provident and Bradford Bank acquisitions were $4 million or $0.03 per common share in the recent quarter. This compares with net after-tax merger-related benefits of $9 million or $0.08 per common share in the third quarter of 2009, which came as a result of our acquisition of Bradford Bank. We expect no further merger-related expenses from either of the two acquisitions.The amortization of core deposits and other intangible assets amounted to $0.09 per common share in the fourth quarter of 2009 and in the linked quarter. Diluted net operating earnings per common share, excluding the amortization of core deposits and other intangibles, as well as merger related items that I just mentioned were $1.16 per common share for the recent quarter, up 18% from $0.98 in the linked quarter. M&T's net operating income for the quarter was $151 million, an increase of 17% from $129 million in the linked quarter.Next, I'd like to cover a few highlights from the balance sheet and the income statement. Intangible equivalent net interest income was $565 million for the fourth quarter, an 8% annualized increase from $553 million in the linked quarter and an increase of 15% from $491 million in the fourth quarter of 2008. The net interest margin continued to expand during the fourth quarter, averaging 3.71%, up from 3.61% in the third quarter. Approximately four basis points of the margin expansion came from repricing on consumer time deposits. An additional four basis points came from a shift in our funding mix, with higher non-maturity savings and  commercial DDA balances replacing time deposits and wholesale borrowing. The remainder of the expansion came from lower rates on wholesale borrowing. Notable during the quarter was a rise in yields on commercial & industrial loans, up nine basis points compared with the third quarter. Looking forward, we expect further widening of the margin for 2010. As for the balance sheet, average loans for the fourth quarter declined approximately $200 million from $52.3 billion, in the third quarter to $52.1 billion. Compared with this year's third quarter, changes in average loans by category were as follows. Commercial & industrial loans declined by 8%. Average loans to auto dealers to finance new model and year inventory grew by an annualized 18% as compared with the third quarter of 2009, while remaining C&I loans balances declined an annualized 10%. The decline in this latter category was exacerbated by pay-downs, charge-offs in both the third and fourth quarters and a reduction in certain non-core customer exposures. Commercial real estate loans and residential real estate loans each grew by an annualized 2%, and consumer loans declined by an annualized 3%. This includes a 14% annualized decline of indirect auto loans, reflecting continued run-off in the out-of-footprint part of that portfolio. This was partially offset by a modest mid-single-digit growth in our home equity lines of credit.Recently, we experienced low single-digit annualized growth in upstate New York, while experiencing low to mid-single-digit decline in the New York City metro region and in Pennsylvania. The decline in commercial and industrial loans from pay downs, charge-offs and exits were concentrated in the mid-Atlantic. Excluding those items, loans in the mid-Atlantic were relatively flat. We continue to see strong growth in core deposits. Average core customer deposits in the fourth quarter, which excludes foreign deposits and CDs over $100,000, as well as excluding any acquisition impact, increased by an annualized 15% from the third quarter, with growth coming in every geographic region. Also notable is the fact that the average non-interest-bearing deposits in the fourth quarter of '09 were up 50% compared with the fourth quarter of 2008. This also excludes the impact from acquisitions.Turning to non-interest income, excluding securities gains and losses and the third quarter $29 million gain from the Bradford acquisition, non-interest income was $300 million for the recent quarter compared with $296 million in the third quarter. Mortgage banking fees were $50 million for the quarter, up from $48 million in the linked quarter. This reflects the impact of wider gain-on-sale margins, partially offset by slightly lower origination volume. Service charges on deposit accounts were $127 million during the quarter, compared with $129 million in the linked quarter. The decline came primarily on the commercial side and was largely attributable to fewer processing days in the fourth quarter compared with the third quarter.M&T's share of operating results of Bayview Lending Group or BLG was a loss of $11 million, unchanged from the linked quarter. BLG's recent performance was largely attributable to an increase in loan loss provisioning. Securities losses in the fourth quarter amounted to $34 million, predominantly reflecting an additional other-than-temporary impairment charges on our available-for-sale securities portfolio. This was down from $47 million of other-than-temporary impairment charges in the third quarter.Operating expenses were well-controlled during the recent quarter. Excluding merger-related expenses and the amortization of intangible assets, operating expenses were $455 million, down from $469 million in the third quarter of '09. The decline was primarily attributable to lower compensation expense, including core salaries, as well as incentive compensation. The fourth quarter's result included a $4 million reversal of the valuation allowance for capitalized residential mortgage servicing rights. This compares to no adjustments to the valuation allowance in the third quarter of '09 and a $19 million addition to the allowance in the fourth quarter of 2008. As of the end of 2009, we have reversed substantially all of the valuation allowance for capitalized residential mortgage servicing revenue. Excluding the benefit from the MSR, other operating expenses also declined slightly.The operating efficiency ratio, which excludes security gains and losses, as well as merger-related items and intangible amortization was 52.7% in the fourth quarter of 2009 compared with 55.2% in the linked quarter and 57% in the fourth quarter of 2008. The decline in efficiency ratio from the fourth quarter of 2008 is impressive, given that it reflects an $18 million increase in the FDIC assessment relative to the fourth quarter of 2008.Overall, credit -- let's turn to credit. Overall credit trends progressed as expected, with stable net charge-offs and a modest increase in non-performing assets. Non-accrual loans increased to $1.3 billion or 2.56% of loans at the end of the recent quarter, up $103 million from $1.2 billion or 2.35% of loans at the end of the previous quarter, an increase of about 8%. Substantially, all of the linked-quarter increase relates to a single commercial real estate loan for $104 million in Manhattan. This represents one of only two non-accrual loans of any significance in our greater New York City Metropolitan area. This particular loan is one I mentioned on the October earnings conference call and for which the recent appraisals indicate that the value of the property continues to be in excess of the loan balance. Despite the move to non-performing status, our outlook with regard to the resolution of this particular credit hasn't changed much. We continue to view the loss content as low and based on our original underwriting. Other non-performing assets, consisting of assets taken into foreclosure of defaulted loans, were $95 million as of December 31, compared with $85 million as of September 30.Net charge-offs for the fourth quarter were $135 million, down from $141 million in the third quarter of 2009. Annualized net charge-offs as a percentage of loans were 1.03%, improved from 1.07% in the linked quarter. Charge-offs for commercial and industrial loans were $31 million in the fourth quarter, down from $71 million in the linked quarter. Net charge-offs for residential builder construction loans were $40 million for the recent quarter, compared with $13 million in the prior quarter. For the full year of 2009, net charge-offs on residential construction credits totaled $92 million, down from $100 million in 2008. Net charge-offs for all other commercial real estate loans were $11 million, compared with $8 million in the third quarter. Net charge-offs on residential real estate loans were $21 million in the fourth quarter, up just $1 million from the linked quarter and net charge-offs on consumer loans was $32 million in the fourth quarter compared with $30 million in the linked quarter. The provision for credit losses was $145 million for the fourth quarter, compared with $154 million in the linked quarter. Provision exceeded net charge-offs by $10 million and increased the allowance for loan losses to $878 million as of the end of 2009. The ratio of allowance for credit losses to legacy M&T loans, which exclude acquired loans against which there's already a credit mark, was up 1.83%, up from 1.81% in the linked quarter. As of December 31, 2008, that ratio was 1.61%.For the full year 2009, charge-offs were $514 million or 1.01% of average loans. We believe this represents the lowest rate among large regional and super regional banks. The loan-loss allowance as of December 31, 2009, was 1.7 times net charge-offs for the past year.Loans past due 90 days are still accruing with $208 million at the end of the recent quarter and included $193 million of loans guaranteed by government-related entities. Those figures were $183 million and $173 million respectively at the end of the sequential quarter. M&T's tangible common equity ratio was 5.13% at the end of the fourth quarter, an increase of 24 basis points from 4.89% at the end of the quarter. Unrealized, pre-tax losses on our available-for-sale investment portfolio were $293 million at the end of the quarter, compared with $313 million at the end of the third quarter and $806 million at the end of 2008.Turning to our outlook, as most of you know, we don't offer much in the way of earnings guidance, but we'll share our thoughts on some general trends. While the economy appears to be stable, the pace of recovery is slow. As a result, we expect both loan and overall earnings, asset growth to be in the low single digits. With the current trends being slightly negative, we'll need to see a turnaround in the current trends by the middle of the year in order to be able to achieve that growth. The demand for credit from customers, whether to build inventories or to expand plant capacity just isn't there yet, and when combined with the portfolios that we have that are in run-off mode, like parts of our indirect auto and asset growth, should be relatively modest. The strong inflows of deposits, particularly on the commercial side, are also an indication that businesses aren't ready to increase investment. As I mentioned earlier, the outlook for interest margin is for additional widening, as two fundamental trends remain in effect. Turnover in the loan portfolio, that is to say, repayments and renewals is pricing in the benefit from today's wider credit spread, and the continued inflows of non-interest-bearing deposits I just mentioned are also a positive. We'd expect less impact, going forward, from the favorable repricing of time deposits.While credit costs remain elevated as the current credit cycle continues to play out, our inflows of loans into non-accruals status and our loss experience continues to be very manageable. Over the past several quarters, it appears that the consumer and the residential real estate credit trends have stabilized, but they're not improving yet. Fortunately, our exposure to these portfolios is relatively modest. We had the lowest charge-off rate among large regional and super regional banks in this year's third quarter. And given our underwriting culture, our habit of addressing problem areas proactively and the trends we've seen in our criticized loan portfolio, we believe we'll continue to report strong relative performance in 2010. As you know, we've always placed a priority on operating efficiency and will continue to do so. That said, as we plan for the future, the area of most uncertainty is in the rising cost of regulation.Finally, I'll remind you that normalized for unusual items, the first quarter's results have tended to be seasonally low for us, reflecting fewer days and higher expenses associated with FICA, accelerated recognition of option expense or equity expense and the 401(k) match. Of course, all of these projections are subject to a number of uncertainties, various assumptions regarding national economic growth, changes in interest rates, political event and other macro-economic factors, which may differ materially from what actually unfolds in the future. We'll now open up the call to questions, before which Christie will briefly review the instructions.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Steven Alexopoulos with JPMorgan.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about -- are all the cost saves and revenue synergies from the two deals now on a run rate?
componenttext: Can you talk about -- are all the cost saves and revenue synergies from the two deals now on a run rate?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the answer is no. And the way you think about that is that when you think about the opportunities that we have on the distribution side, that just takes some time. So with seven months through the transaction, I would think that 2010, particularly
componenttext: I think the answer is no. And the way you think about that is that when you think about the opportunities that we have on the distribution side, that just takes some time. So with seven months through the transaction, I would think that 2010, particularly for our retail folks, we'll be continuing to sort of work through the distribution-type issues, which at the end of the day, will result in additional expense savings. I think we're more than halfway through the expense savings. In fact, I know we're well more than halfway through the expense savings. On the revenue side, I think that the same is true there. The idea of sort of optimizing the work you do on the revenue side, particularly with sort of offering all your services to the new customers, I think that takes a little time. So we would hope that there's continued opportunity through the year 2010 on that side, as well. It's harder to identify it on the revenue side.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Second question, looking at the $6 billion of commercial real estate loans in the New York City area, one, can you talk about what the renewal schedule looks like this year and maybe next year? And then second, are you seeing anything in terms of early-st
componenttext: Second question, looking at the $6 billion of commercial real estate loans in the New York City area, one, can you talk about what the renewal schedule looks like this year and maybe next year? And then second, are you seeing anything in terms of early-stage delinquencies there?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start I think your questions in the order. It's a tough question to answer because when you look at the renewals, if you think about what we do, it matters what year that they're coming from. So the thing that helps us most is that from, say,
componenttext: Well, let me start I think your questions in the order. It's a tough question to answer because when you look at the renewals, if you think about what we do, it matters what year that they're coming from. So the thing that helps us most is that from, say, 2004 through the third quarter of 2007, we kept our commercial real estate portfolio relatively flat. So maybe the numbers in December will fall at something like $5.1 billion. By the time we got to September of '07 we're at about $5.3 billion, somewhere in that range. We've put some stuff on in the fourth quarter of '07. So the average life of our portfolio, my guess would be somewhere around five years, but if you think about what's coming to renewal next year, a lot of it would be things that were de-booked as far as long ago as 10 years. What's good about that is that they're not booked in anywhere near the roughly [ph] times. And so you have much more equity component in there. If you go back to 2004, if you think of our portfolio as a five-year portfolio, it would give you kind of an average, let's say an average life of five years. You're basically saying we must have booked $1 billion a year to do that. I would say in 2004, for example, we booked half of that because we just couldn't figure out what was going on. So on the renewals that we'll see this year, I would guess that the most of them are coming from things that were booked way before 2004. And we're still doing our work on the schedules. I think at some point we're going to publish that maturity schedule, but the more we get into it, in order to sort of give you something that gives you a sense of our portfolio, just sort of takes us a little bit of time. So that's on that sense. In terms of the portfolio, as I said the last call, we had a couple of credits that we sort of have -- what I would call in our watch list. One of them came into non-performing this quarter. There hasn't been anything new that we've seen through our portfolio reviews. And our portfolio reviews are pretty granular. I think the thing to think about is that because we're so granular and focused on getting ahead of the problem, and because the lead time is long, my sense is that to the extent that we have additional credits that go into non-performing, you're going to sort of hear about them so much before they happen. So no real change, we haven't seen any sort of additional problem credits and delinquencies in the New York City portfolio. Last thing I'll say on this, if I could, is that reflecting back on 2009, actually you learn a lot. Right? So we have no losses in the portfolio in 2009. And we actually had nothing rolling to non-performing but for this last credit that we just took this quarter. So when you look back at that, really, one of the most significant factors is not that actual credit wasn't weakening in New York City, it was that most, if not all of our sponsors, were willing to step up because they saw real value in the properties, and they're willing to kick in additional resources if they were needed in order to keep the project moving forward. So when we look at '09 and we look at our sponsors behave and what the result was, we felt pretty good about sort of where we are today.
