componenttext: How should we think about the loan on deposit ratio trending here specially with your comments on holding more resi mortgage loans, but maybe with the makeshift from deposit growth to collateralized deposits which really gets excluded from this map?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Loan deposits ratio's a proxy. It's all about liquidity and really we're using those resis to replace the run-off in the securities book. So on the profile basis, it doesn't change it very much. I will say that you've seen, if you look at the number I thi
componenttext: Loan deposits ratio's a proxy. It's all about liquidity and really we're using those resis to replace the run-off in the securities book. So on the profile basis, it doesn't change it very much. I will say that you've seen, if you look at the number I think or deposit growth was flat but what that's really driven by sort of get over $450 million, in that was over $450 million of a decline in government deposits from the second to the third. And what you'll see going into the fourth, is that they seasonally spike back up. Right? So I think there's not been much change the deposit growth is lower than we've seen in the past and that probably is just consistent with the idea that the slow lending environment is sort of filing out a little bit as well, but there's not a lot of the news there.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then can you just remind us from liquidity side, you've been building a little bit of excess liquidity here with the stronger deposit growth. Is your plans to deploy that helped offset declines driven from secured repricing here?
componenttext: Then can you just remind us from liquidity side, you've been building a little bit of excess liquidity here with the stronger deposit growth. Is your plans to deploy that helped offset declines driven from secured repricing here?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We said in the script, we talked about this idea of putting on repost to collateralized our government deposits. I mean, if you wanted to make a little more running and do that, you'd put on securities, but I think we're a little cautious because we think
componenttext: We said in the script, we talked about this idea of putting on repost to collateralized our government deposits. I mean, if you wanted to make a little more running and do that, you'd put on securities, but I think we're a little cautious because we think that the prices of securities are artificially inflated today, based on the government buying and all the news out there. So really what we're doing is nothing, and we're just holding our options open. But you're right we would have grown if we wanted to sort wanted the balance to be a little bit bigger and we could make money, but I think we're still a little cautious and uncertain.

componenttextpreview: You know what, why don't we think about doing that and we'll sort of decide how to disclose that publicly. I guess what I would say is, it's hard to do off-the-cuff right? What I would say is I would guess that when we finish of this year, our cost, which
componenttext: You know what, why don't we think about doing that and we'll sort of decide how to disclose that publicly. I guess what I would say is, it's hard to do off-the-cuff right? What I would say is I would guess that when we finish of this year, our cost, which today goes through revenue, would be probably $15 million to $17 million for the year, somewhere in that range. Just to give you some sense of what we're doing and then that's tied to a number, I know we probably get somewhere between 25 and 35 repurchase request of 25 loans to 35 loans in a course of a month, and then some smaller percentage of that is actually are things that we actually settle on and have to pay, because people are firing a lot of things back to you, but quite frankly not all of them have a lot of substance. So those are some numbers to start with and then think about mentioning that.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: What about René because you were selling all day private labels, is there any way to quantify how much risk there might be in that area?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean we probably sold, I don't know $2.5 billion of Alt-A loans into the market and the thing to think about is, if you follow the stories that are going on, one good thing is that when you merit to the 1.3 that we started with several years ago a
componenttext: Well, I mean we probably sold, I don't know $2.5 billion of Alt-A loans into the market and the thing to think about is, if you follow the stories that are going on, one good thing is that when you merit to the 1.3 that we started with several years ago and you look at the credit quality of that all day loan book and compare it to the national averages, it's better. We didn't like it but it's better than average. And then the other thing is that we're early in the chain, right? We originated these loans, so all the noise about title and who has the right titles to it is a little bit less of an issue for us because there were things where we actually did the work to pass the title, right? So we don't have an estimate today but I'm not overly worried about it. If the trend comes it will that have been over a long period of time and you'll have fair warning. But we haven't seen a requested today on those books.

componenttext: I'd say, 1/3 of it is maybe prepayments and those types of things, the payments on non-accruals. componenttext: Well, I think over the long term, it's everywhere but a big part of it is in the commercial side and I think it's just consistent with what you've been seeing in the downward trend and loan demand, and I think those 2 things will reverse themselves together. We had, if you look over a longer period of time, maybe 2 years, we've made a big concerted effort to focus on our deposit products and on the commercial side, our treasury management services, and we definitely have gained access to new customers for over that time period. So we're probably much better position going into the future than we were in the past.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then the question on the funding side, on the borrowing side. Can give us a little bit of color as to what your strategy is there, in terms of how you're managing the longer-term borrowings from an extension perspective or cost p
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then the question on the funding side, on the borrowing side. Can give us a little bit of color as to what your strategy is there, in terms of how you're managing the longer-term borrowings from an extension perspective or cost perspective?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess the answer to that is I have to start with is our short term position. We are very comfortable with our liquidity position and in fact, we are probably we could, as one of the other callers mentioned, we could afford probably more short term
componenttext: Yes, I guess the answer to that is I have to start with is our short term position. We are very comfortable with our liquidity position and in fact, we are probably we could, as one of the other callers mentioned, we could afford probably more short term borrowings if we wanted to, but we don't necessarily see what the opportunities are on the asset side, so we haven't done anything there. And then the long term, we sort of bucket everything out in our long term borrowings. We look at our FHLB borrowings and as they begin to mature, we kind of look at them. We don't see any problem with rolling them over but pretty much, we don't expect much of a change, I would say if you look 12 months out maybe we will lessen them over and use a little bit more short term, but I don't expect much of a change and the borrowing costs really hasn't changed much for the last 6 months in those periods because LIBOR's been flat and they're all LIBOR based borrowings.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: And we will return to Matthew Clark of KBW.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know your C&I related charge-offs can bounce around from time to time. Just curious as it relates to the latest snick exam, whether or not some of that was tied to that or was it just more small-business just struggling?
componenttext: I know your C&I related charge-offs can bounce around from time to time. Just curious as it relates to the latest snick exam, whether or not some of that was tied to that or was it just more small-business just struggling?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Much less than. The Shared National Credit Exam didn't have much of an impact on us. We had a couple of credits. We had maybe something like $6 million or so with the largest related to provider pharmaceutical services. Then we had some smaller, sort of $
componenttext: Much less than. The Shared National Credit Exam didn't have much of an impact on us. We had a couple of credits. We had maybe something like $6 million or so with the largest related to provider pharmaceutical services. Then we had some smaller, sort of $4 million or less, in terms of charge-offs around companies or manufacturers, providers of entertainment, nonentertainment businesses but smaller venues. So there isn't really a theme in the C&I book. As I said, the overall seems to be improving in the middle market space. I think it's interesting you mention small business because that sort of the 1 place as we look over quarter-over-quarter where you really don't see much any improvement in the business banking space. In fact, I think our charge-offs in the business banking were probably went from like something like $12 million to $15 million, right? And what you're seeing there is that as the economy remains very, very slow, there's uncertainty, those are the guys that are most affected and as the length of the downturn remains very long, you just continue to put more and more pressure on those small businesses. For us, as you can see kind of $12 million to $15 million is not really all that material but there but it does tell you a lot about the broader economy. That's where all the jobs come from, right?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. And then on the new problem front, it was about I think $102 million if you gross it up for charge-offs this quarter, after I think being nonexistent last quarter. It sounds like the migration continues to improve but just curious as to the source
componenttext: Right. And then on the new problem front, it was about I think $102 million if you gross it up for charge-offs this quarter, after I think being nonexistent last quarter. componenttext: As much what I have mentioned earlier. I think, again, that you saw $27 million of addition in the construction development. If I look at where those were, a couple of them, as I said, $15 million of it was Providence, so a couple of them where in Mid Atlantic space. We had one that was, I think it's in Pennsylvania but I can quite see it in front of me. So that was really what drove most of it. In terms of Manhattan, we haven't seen much of a change. We still have the 1 large property that's in the ORE and that's hasn't moved yet but we're working on it so.

componenttext: I mean I guess what I would say is that we feel pretty good about our overall condition and our health. I'm still very positive that there'll be a fair amount of opportunities for M&T in the future. And I have not seen anything that would tell me that, that's not to be the case. Today, what you see is a lot of small institutions that don't have a lot of strategic value who have difficulties from a regulatory standpoint or performance standpoint. But I don't think that's sort of where we make our hay. I think it comes from as people think through the difficult environment, and they think about who they want to partner with as opposed to sell their institution, then the opportunities for us are probably going to be pretty bright.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the M&T Bank Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Don MacLeod, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin your conference.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paula, and good morning. I’d like to welcome everyone to M&T’s Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call, both by telephone and through the webcast. If you have not read our earnings release we issued earlier this morning, you may access
componenttext:
Thank you, Paula, and good morning. I’d like to welcome everyone to M&T’s Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call, both by telephone and through the webcast. If you have not read our earnings release we issued earlier this morning, you may access it along with the financial tables and schedules from our website, www.mtb.com and by clicking on the Investor Relations link.
Also, before we start, I’d like to mention that comments made during this call may contain forward-looking statements relating to the banking industry and to M&T Bank Corporation. M&T encourages participants to refer to our SEC filings including those found on Forms 8-K, 10-K and 10-Q for a complete discussion of forward-looking statements.
Now I’d like to introduce our Chief Financial Officer, Rene Jones.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don, and welcome, everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call today. I believe with the last call this morning, among our regional and subregional peers, so when we're finished you can settle down and try to assess what it all means. I'd lik
componenttext:
Thank you, Don, and welcome, everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call today. I believe with the last call this morning, among our regional and subregional peers, so when we're finished you can settle down and try to assess what it all means. I'd like to cover the highlights of the recent quarter, after which I'll take your questions. 
For the third quarter of 2010, diluted earnings per common share were $1.48, up from $1.46 in the previous quarter and $0.97 in the third quarter of 2009. Net income for the recent quarter was $192 million, up from $189 million in the linked quarter and $128 million in last year's third quarter.
Recall that our GAAP results for the third quarter of '09 included $9 million of after-tax merger-related benefit, arising from a gain on the Bradford Bank acquisition, which was partially offset by merger-related expenses arising from both the Provident and Bradford transactions. There were no merger-related expenses in this year's second quarter or third quarter. 
Our results for the third quarter of 2010 included after-tax expense from the amortization of intangible assets amounting to $8 million or $0.07 per share. This compares to $9 million and $0.07 per common share in the linked quarter and $10 million or $0.09 per common share in the year-ago quarter.
Net operating income, which excludes the amortization of intangibles, as well as the net merger-related benefit in last year's third quarter, was $200 million for the recent quarter, up from $198 million in the linked quarter and $129 million in last year's third quarter. Diluted net operating income per share was $1.55 for the third quarter of 2010, up from $1.53 per share in the prior quarter and up 58% from the $0.98 per share in last year's third quarter. And according to the SEC guidelines, this morning's press release contained a tabular reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP results, including intangible assets and equity.
Turning to the balance sheet and income statement. Taxable equivalent net interest income was $576 million for the third quarter, up from $573 million in the linked quarter and up 4% from $553 million in the third quarter of 2009. The net interest margin expanded slightly during the third quarter, rising to 3.87% from 3.84% in the second quarter of 2010 and was up 26 basis points from the 3.61% in last year's third quarter.
The yield on earnings assets was up about 2 basis points during the quarter, primarily reflecting favorable loan repricing. We also realized that benefit of prepayment penalties and the recognition of cash interest payments on non-accruing loans that was comparable to the levels that we saw in the second quarter. The cost of funds declined by 1 basis points, reflecting the benefit of a shift in mix of core deposits from time deposits to non-maturity savings product.
Looking forward, we seem to be on track with our previous comments back in January, that our full year margin would not likely be higher than 3.80% through 3.85%. Through the first 9 months of 2010, the margin was a 3.83%.
As for the balance sheet. Average earnings assets declined by an annualized 5% as compared to the second quarter of 2010, and this included the impact from $382 million decrease in investment securities and a $443 million or 3% annualized decline in average loan balances. On an end-of-period basis, total loans for this year's third quarter declined by $270 million or 2% annualized from the end of period of the prior quarter. On the same basis by category, C&I loans declined by $229 million or 7% annualized. Commercial real estate loans declined by $33 million or 1%. Consumer loans also declined by $33 million or 1%, while residential real estate loans grew by $25 million or 2%. 
Despite the overall pressure on loan volumes, we've seen a few encouraging signs. On an end-of-period basis, the pace of decline in total loans has slowed from rates seen in each of this year's first and second quarters. In the final month of the quarter, we saw a growth in commercial and industrial loan and stable commercial real estate loans. Finally, much of the quarterly decline appeared to be driven by lower utilization rates as overall commitments rose.
Turning to non-interest income, non-interest income was $290 million for the recent quarter, up from $274 million in the linked quarter, and the recent quarter's results included $8 million of securities losses compared with $22 million in the prior quarter. Mortgage banking fees were $61 million for the third quarter compared with $47 million in the linked quarter.
Origination volumes were 29 million -- excuse me. Origination volumes were up 29% during the recent quarter, reflecting in part the record low interest rates, while gain on sale margins widened further from this year's second quarter. Service charges on deposit accounts were $118 million during the recent quarter compared with $129 million in the linked quarter. The 9% decline was attributable to the implementation of the new Regulation E. The customer response to the new regulation has been consistent with or perhaps slightly better than our expectation. Our decision not to charge NSF fees on transactions less than $10 has had a negative impact on overall fees, but has met with the favorable response from our customers.
Turning to expenses. Operating expenses, which exclude the amortization of tangible assets, were $467 million compared with $461 million in the linked quarter. This year's third quarter results included a $3 million addition to the impairment allowance for capitalized mortgage servicing rights. Compared with the $2 million addition in the allowance in the second quarter, last year's third quarter results included no adjustment to the impairment allowance.
The efficiency ratio, which excludes securities gains and losses, as well as intangible amortization, was 53.4% in the third quarter, up just slightly from the 53.1% in the linked quarter.
Next, let's turn to credit. Overall, credit trends remained stable with the linked quarter and considerably improved from the prior year. Criticized and classified loans declined for the fourth consecutive quarter. Non-accrual loans were $1.1 billion or 2.16% of loans at the end of the recent quarter compared with $1.09 billion or 2.13% of loans at the end of the previous quarter. 
Foreclosed assets were unchanged from the previous quarter at quarter end at $193 million. The nonperforming asset ratio, which is nonperforming assets divided by total loans plus real estate and other foreclosed assets, was 2.53% as of September 30, 2010, compared with 2.50% at June 30.
Annualized net charge-offs as a percentage of loans were 73 basis points in the third quarter compared with 64 basis points in the linked quarter. For the 9 months ended September 30, annualized net charge-offs were 70 basis points, down from 100 basis points in the year earlier period.
Net charge-offs for commercial and industrial loans were $33 million in the linked quarter compared with $9 million -- in the third quarter compared with $9 million in the linked quarter. Net charge offs for residential builder construction loans were $11 million for the recent quarter compared with $17 million in the prior quarter.
Net charge-offs for all other commercial real estate loans were $7 million, down from $19 million in the second quarter. Net charge-offs in residential real estate loans were $17 million in the third quarter compared to $13 million in the linked quarter, and net charge-offs on consumer loans were $25 million in the third quarter compared to $24 million in the linked quarter.
The provision for credit losses was $93 million in the third quarter compared with $85 million in the linked quarter. The allowance for loan losses was unchanged at $895 million at the end of the third quarter. The ratio of allowance to credit losses to legacy M&T loans, which excludes acquired loans that were marked to fair value at the acquisition, was also unchanged at 1.86% as compared to June 30. The loan loss allowance as of September 30 was 2.4x annual net charge-offs for the recent quarter and 2.5x annualized net charge-offs year-to-date.
We disclosed loans past due 90 days but still accruing separately from non-accrual loans because they are deemed to be well secured and in the process of collection, which is to say that there is a minimal risk of principal loss. In our case, that's particularly true. Loans 90 days past due were $215 million at the end of the recent quarter. Of these, $194 million or 90% are guaranteed by government-related entities. Those figures were $203 million and $188 million, respectively, at the end of June.
M&T's tangible common equity ratio was 5.96% at the end of the third quarter, an increase of 21 basis points from 5.75% at the end of June. The Tier 1 common ratio was an estimated 6.4% as of the end of the recent quarter, improved from 6.15% at the end of the second quarter.
Turning to our outlook. M&T's credit trends continue to compare favorably with those of the industry overall, and we're seeing signs that the economy continues to stabilize, although unemployment remains high. The decline in loan volumes has continued to moderate, and we expect that trend to continue but at a slow pace.
Late in the third quarter, we began to retain conforming mortgages originated through our retail network to hold on the balance sheet. With the run-off in our securities book, our level of asset sensitivity has been getting a little higher than we like. We believe that it makes more sense in the current environment to retain our own production of mortgage loans rather than to sell them and simultaneously purchase securities from others. For the near term, this action will reduce our residential gain on sale revenues, which ultimately will be offset by higher net interest income in subsequent periods.
We're also thinking through the best approach to collateralize seasonal inflows of government deposits. And to the extent that we choose to use repurchase agreements, we'd expect a modest benefit to net interest income in the future and the reduction of net -- in the net interest margin by a few basis points.
Finally, 2 weeks ago, Allied Irish Banks took their initial steps to divest their shareholdings in M&T that they've held since we bought Allfirst Financial from them in 2003. In doing so, they sold 26.7 million notes convertible into 26.7 million shares of M&T stock following the approval by AIB shareholders. The notes were priced at $77.50 each, valuing them at 2.5x our June 30 tangible book value and 20.2 million of those notes were sold to 123 institutional investors, so 6.5 million of the notes were sold through the retail channel. We believe the successful completion of this offering demonstrates the strength of M&T's access to the capital markets.
In closing, I would remind you that all of our projections are subject to a number of uncertainties and various assumptions regarding national and regional economic growth, changes in interest rates, political events and other macroeconomic factors, which may differ materially from what actually unfolds in the future. We'll now open up the call to questions, before which Paula will briefly review the instructions.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Bob Ramsey of FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Bob Ramsey of FBR Capital Markets.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's interesting that you mentioned you all are beginning the portfolio conforming mortgages, and then historically, you felt that the return on capital on those assets didn't justify having a big portfolio. Could you just maybe expand a little bi
componenttext: I think it's interesting that you mentioned you all are beginning the portfolio conforming mortgages, and then historically, you felt that the return on capital on those assets didn't justify having a big portfolio. Could you just maybe expand a little bit on the change, particularly with mortgage rates as low as they are, and also talk about, are these ARMs? Are they fixed-rate mortgages? Or what is sort of the focus?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that -- that's a good way to start off, Bob. I think that we don't have a difference in change. We've not changed our thinking. We still have the same view of what the returns generally are on residential mortgage, given the role -- especially giv
componenttext: I think that -- that's a good way to start off, Bob. I think that we don't have a difference in change. We've not changed our thinking. We still have the same view of what the returns generally are on residential mortgage, given the role -- especially given the role of Freddie and Fannie, but having said that, we long sort of viewed residential mortgage as substitute for securities. They have the same profile, and we lumped them all into our discretionary portfolio. So what is unusual today is that there's a big difference in both rates and yields and returns that you can get on mortgages and securities today. And so if you start thinking about it, it really doesn't make sense for us to be selling assets at the same time we're buying them because we're basically just giving up the transaction spread. So economically, the best thing to sort of do to balance out your portfolio is just slow down the amount that you're selling, and it sort of helps keep ourselves neutral. So it's the cheapest way to keep the balance sheet where we'd like it.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. That helps. And then could you also maybe talk a little bit about your plans for your trust preferreds as Basel III and U.S. capital rules are slowly getting a little bit clearer. I know they're largely callable. Do you all anticipate calling them a
componenttext: Okay. That helps. And then could you also maybe talk a little bit about your plans for your trust preferreds as Basel III and U.S. capital rules are slowly getting a little bit clearer. I know they're largely callable. Do you all anticipate calling them at some point? And if so, how would that funding be replaced, and what might be the impact on funding cost?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well -- okay. So you've got a 2-part question in a sense. The first part is big chunk of them, $450 million or so, just are cheap debt. I mean they're priced so slow that we would never sort of call them, we would retain them. And then the second part of
componenttext: Well -- okay. So you've got a 2-part question in a sense. The first part is big chunk of them, $450 million or so, just are cheap debt. I mean they're priced so slow that we would never sort of call them, we would retain them. And then the second part of that, half of it is, your question is, sort of what happens with capital, and as you know, we really won't find out probably for another 6 months exactly what the rules will be around that. So I realized that they'll probably lose their capital content, but I guess the big question really is what is the sort of -- what are all the rules around risk-weighting. And when you think of them and see, if you were to sort of stack up our capital structure versus everybody else, much more of our Tier 1 risk-weighted capital or let's say Tier 1 common equity is just dependent upon common equity, right, so we've never -- what our likely thinking is going to be to think about the risk-weighting of our balance sheet. And in our minds, is the risk-weighting today appropriate, or do we need to have a different one, which would basically mean maybe you'd hold more residential mortgages or some other types of securities slightly. In terms of what we do with the rest of it, it depends on what the rules are, but it's all callable, so we would take it out if it was necessary. But I don't think you still have enough information around what the exact rules are going to be to make that decision today.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from John Pancari of Evercore Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from John Pancari of Evercore Partners.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: René, could you talk a little bit more about your loan growth outlook, specifically the trends that you saw in September? It's interesting that you actually saw some C&I growth and stabilization in CRE. Is that something you think could continue given th
componenttext: René, could you talk a little bit more about your loan growth outlook, specifically the trends that you saw in September? It's interesting that you actually saw some C&I growth and stabilization in CRE. Is that something you think could continue given the stabilization in the utilization rates?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that if I go back to where we were in January, what we were talking about is that we had planned to have a certain amount of loan growth for the year, and we didn't expect to see much in the first half, but we thought it would turn around by the s
componenttext: I think that if I go back to where we were in January, what we were talking about is that we had planned to have a certain amount of loan growth for the year, and we didn't expect to see much in the first half, but we thought it would turn around by the second. I think all of that is happening. It's just happening in a much slower pace. So that's why I mentioned the fact that if you look at first, to second, second to third, and then now, this last quarter, you see a moderation in the decline. The other thing that I think is relatively encouraging is that when we look at this quarter's decline, almost all of it on the commercial side is lower utilization, and I think what you're seeing is we're kind of working our way across the commercial bank. We've seen, for example, in the mid-Atlantic, a number of customers who are paying down debt, repositioning themselves. We've seen in the commercial real estate space a number of pretty well-healed commercial real estate folks actually just looking at the liquidity in their portfolio, maybe selling down some projects to improve the overall liquidity position. But overall, our commitments are up. So I think people are just on hold. The rates are low; they're trying to lock in some credit today, but they're not necessarily using it because they're not yet investing. And I would guess that the trends will continue to improve, but I wouldn't expect a big spike up in loan growth all of a sudden. The other thing I'd point out is that in the volume of loans that went through our senior loan committee, they were higher than last quarter, and the returns were better.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. On the NPLs, just -- you saw them go up in the quarter despite the increase in charge-offs. I know you've indicated that the watch list improved, but can you talk a little bit about the inflows into nonperformers this quarter and wha
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. On the NPLs, just -- you saw them go up in the quarter despite the increase in charge-offs. I know you've indicated that the watch list improved, but can you talk a little bit about the inflows into nonperformers this quarter and what that may mean in the coming quarters?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the increase was up $9 million. And I think what's most interesting to me is that in that $9 million increase, there was a $27 million increase in construction and development. And of that $27 million increase in construction and development, $15
componenttext: Yes. So the increase was up $9 million. And I think what's most interesting to me is that in that $9 million increase, there was a $27 million increase in construction and development. And of that $27 million increase in construction and development, $15 million came from the Provident loans in the mark-to-market, right, so you're not going to see a lot of content coming from there. The continued positive trend was that C&I was down $17 million; right? So when we look at construction and development, this is a portfolio that we've marked before, or a portfolio that we've sort of taken -- we reserved for in the balance sheet. And so there are really no surprises there. So I think as Don has been saying for sometime, you're just going to get some lumpiness as we move our way and things improve. It will take some time, and this is one of the quarters where we saw some more of the C&D actually fall from the classified book into nonperforming.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Craig Siegenthaler of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question is from Craig Siegenthaler of Crédit Suisse.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: How should we think about the loan-to-deposit ratio trending here, specially with your comments on holding more resi mortgage loans, but maybe with the mix shift from deposit growth to collateralized deposits, which really gets excluded from this math?
componenttext: How should we think about the loan-to-deposit ratio trending here, specially with your comments on holding more resi mortgage loans, but maybe with the mix shift from deposit growth to collateralized deposits, which really gets excluded from this math?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean loan deposit-to-ratio is a proxy. It's all about liquidity, and really, we're using the resis to replace the run-off in the securities book. So on a profile basis, it doesn't change it very much. I will say that you've seen, if you look at the
componenttext: Yes. I mean loan deposit-to-ratio is a proxy. It's all about liquidity, and really, we're using the resis to replace the run-off in the securities book. So on a profile basis, it doesn't change it very much. I will say that you've seen, if you look at the numbers, I think our deposit growth was flat, but what that's really driven by is -- it sort of gets [ph] over $450 million. In that was over $450 million of a decline in government deposits from the second to the third. And what you'll see going into the fourth is that they seasonally spike back up. Right? So I think there's not been much change. The deposit growth is lower than we've seen in past -- in the past, and that probably is just consistent with the idea that the slow lending environment is sort of falling out a little bit as well, but there's not a lot of a news there.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just can you remind us from the liquidity side, you've been building a little bit of excess liquidity here with the stronger deposit growth. Is your plans to deploy that and help offset declines in NIM driven from security pricing here?
componenttext: And then just can you remind us from the liquidity side, you've been building a little bit of excess liquidity here with the stronger deposit growth. Is your plans to deploy that and help offset declines in NIM driven from security pricing here?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We said in the script, we talked about this idea of putting on repos to collateralize our government deposits. I mean, if you wanted to make a little more money and do that, you'd put on securities, but I think we're a little cautious because we think tha
componenttext: We said in the script, we talked about this idea of putting on repos to collateralize our government deposits. I mean, if you wanted to make a little more money and do that, you'd put on securities, but I think we're a little cautious because we think that the prices of securities are artificially inflated today, based on the government buying and all the news out there. So really what we're doing is nothing, and we're just holding our options open. But you're right, we would have room if we wanted to sort of -- wanted the balance sheet to be a little bit bigger and we could make a little bit more money, but I think we're still a little cautious and uncertain.

componenttextpreview: You know what, Alex, why don't we think about doing that and then we'll sort of decide how to disclose that publicly. I guess what I would say is, it's hard to do off-the-cuff; right? What I would say is that I would guess that when we finish this year, o
componenttext: You know what, Alex, why don't we think about doing that and then we'll sort of decide how to disclose that publicly. I guess what I would say is, it's hard to do off-the-cuff; right? What I would say is that I would guess that when we finish this year, our cost, which today go through revenue, would be probably $15 million to $17 million for the year, somewhere in that range. And to give you some sense of what we're doing -- and then that's tied to a number -- I know we probably get somewhere between 25 and 35 request -- repurchase request of 25 loans to 35 loans in a course of a month, and then some smaller percentage of that is actually are things that we actually settle on and have to pay, right, because people are firing a lot of things back to you, but quite frankly, not all of them have a lot of substance; right? So those are some numbers to start with, and then let us think about dimensioning that.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: What about, René, in terms of -- because you were selling Alt-A, right, private labels, is there any way to quantify how much risk there might be in that area?
componenttext: What about, René, in terms of -- because you were selling Alt-A, right, private labels, is there any way to quantify how much risk there might be in that area?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, it's something we'll put -- we probably sold, I don't know, $2.5 billion of Alt-A loans into the market. And the thing to think about is, if you follow the whole stories that are going on, one good thing is that when you -- if you merit [ph]
componenttext: Well, I mean, it's something we'll put -- we probably sold, I don't know, $2.5 billion of Alt-A loans into the market. And the thing to think about is, if you follow the whole stories that are going on, one good thing is that when you -- if you merit [ph] to the 1.3 that we started with several years ago and you look at the credit quality of that Alt-A loan book and compare it to the national averages, it's better. We didn't like it, but it's better than average. And then the other thing is that we're early in the chain; right? We originated these loans. So all the noise about title and who has the right titles to it is a little bit less of an issue for us because there were things where we actually did the work to pass the title; right? So we don't have an estimate today, but I'm not overly worried about it. If the trend comes, and it will happen over a long period of time and you'll have fair warning, but we haven't seen a request today on those books.

componenttext: Well, I mean, I think the issues that are out there today touch all services; right? And so technically, yes, but to the extent to which is out there, I don't know. componenttext: Maybe just one final question. The yield on commercial real estate loans was up to around 485. What is that without the repayment fees? Is that around 450? And do you expect the fees to -- prepayments to continue through year end?

componenttext: I'd say 1/3 of it is maybe prepayments and those types of things, the payments on non-accruals. I'd say 1/3 of it is the fact that we had some repricing off of the book, particularly the book that's based on 3 months LIBOR. And then there was just sort of some smaller yield adjustments, but that would be the breakout. So the LIBOR thing can move every 3 months or so, and the prepayment penalty is really not all that surprising with the low rate environment; right?

componenttext: I wish I could, but I really don't have a good sense of that, and I think the way to think about it is much likely address the Reg E regulation; right? we kind of did a lot of work around it and -- but weren't able to provide a lot of estimates, and then as we got closer to it, we gave you some good ballpark sense, but still there are rules to be written in and a work to be done on our part to think through that issue.

componenttext: Well, I think over the long term, it's really -- it's everywhere, but a big part of it is in the commercial side, and I think it's just consistent with what you've been seeing in the downward trend and loan demand, and I think those 2 things will reverse themselves together. We had, if you look over a longer period of time, maybe 2 years, we've made a big concerted effort to focus on our deposit products and on the commercial side our treasury management services, and we definitely have gained access to new customers over that time period. So we're probably much better positioned going into the future than we were in the past.

componenttext: We had a few million dollars of increase in ORE cost from some reappraisals. componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just a question on the funding side, on the borrowing side. Can you just give a little bit of color as to what your strategy is there, in terms of how you're managing the longer-term borrowings from an extension perspective or cost perspective?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess the answer to that is I have to start with is our short-term position. So we're very comfortable with our liquidity position and, in fact, we're probably we could, as one of the other callers mentioned, we could afford probably more short-ter
componenttext: Yes. I guess the answer to that is I have to start with is our short-term position. So we're very comfortable with our liquidity position and, in fact, we're probably we could, as one of the other callers mentioned, we could afford probably more short-term borrowings if we wanted to, but we just -- we don't necessarily see what the opportunities are on the asset side, so we haven't done anything there. And in the long term, we sort of bucket everything out in our long-term borrowings, so we look at our FHLB borrowings. And as they begin to mature, we kind of look at them. We don't see any problem with rolling them over, but pretty much, we don't expect much of a change. I would say if you look 12 months out maybe we will lessen them over and use a little bit more short term, but I don't expect much of a change, and the borrowing costs really hasn't changed much for the last 6 months in those periods because LIBOR has been flat, and they're all LIBOR-based borrowings.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: And we will return to Matthew Clark of KBW.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know your C&I-related charge-offs can bounce around from time to time. Just curious as it relates to the latest SNC exam, whether or not some of that was tied to that? Or was it just more small-business just struggling?
componenttext: I know your C&I-related charge-offs can bounce around from time to time. Just curious as it relates to the latest SNC exam, whether or not some of that was tied to that? Or was it just more small-business just struggling?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Much less than that. We are -- the Shared National Credit exam didn't have much of an impact on us. We had a couple of credits. We had maybe something like $6 million or so, with the largest related to provider of pharmaceutical services. And then we had
componenttext: Much less than that. We are -- the Shared National Credit exam didn't have much of an impact on us. We had a couple of credits. We had maybe something like $6 million or so, with the largest related to provider of pharmaceutical services. And then we had some smaller sort of $4 million or less in terms of charge-offs around companies or manufacturers, providers of entertainment, nonentertainment businesses but smaller venues. So there isn't really a theme in the C&I book. As I said, the overall seems to be improving in the middle market space. I think it's interesting you mentioned small business because that's sort of the one place as we look over quarter-over-quarter where you really don't see much, if any, improvement in the business banking space. In fact, I think our charge-offs in the business banking were probably went from like -- something like $12 million to $15 million; right? And what you're seeing there is that as the economy remains very, very slow, there's uncertainty, those are the guys that are most affected. And as the length of the downturn remains very long, you just continue to put more and more pressure on those small businesses. For us, as you can see, kind of $12 million to $15 million is not really all that material, but it does tell you a lot about the broader economy. That's where all the jobs come from; right?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. And then on the new problem front, it was about I think $102 million if you gross it up for charge-offs this quarter, after I think being nonexistent last quarter. And I know it sounds like the migration continues to improve, but just curious as to
componenttext: Right. And then on the new problem front, it was about I think $102 million if you gross it up for charge-offs this quarter, after I think being nonexistent last quarter. componenttext: No. Yes, I mean, as much what I have mentioned earlier. I think, again, that you saw about a $27 million of addition in the construction and development. componenttextpreview: I mean I guess what I would say is that we feel pretty good about our overall condition and our health. I'm still very positive that there'll be a fair amount of opportunities for M&T in the future. And I have not seen anything that would tell me that, th
componenttext: I mean I guess what I would say is that we feel pretty good about our overall condition and our health. I'm still very positive that there'll be a fair amount of opportunities for M&T in the future. And I have not seen anything that would tell me that, that's not going to be the case. Today, what you see is a lot of small institutions that don't have a lot of strategic value who have difficulties from a regulatory standpoint or performance standpoint. But I don't think that's sort of where we make our hay. I think it comes from as people think through the difficult environment, and they think about who they want to partner with as opposed to sell their institution, then the opportunities for us are probably going to be pretty bright.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the M&T Bank Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Don MacLeod, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin your
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the M&T Bank Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Don MacLeod, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin your conference.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paula, and good morning. I’d like to welcome everyone to M&T’s Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call, both by telephone and through the webcast. If you have not read our earnings release we issued earlier this morning, you may access
componenttext:
Thank you, Paula, and good morning. I’d like to welcome everyone to M&T’s Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call, both by telephone and through the webcast. If you have not read our earnings release we issued earlier this morning, you may access it along with the financial tables and schedules from our website, www.mtb.com, and by clicking on the Investor Relations link.
Also, before we start, I’d like to mention that comments made during this call may contain forward-looking statements relating to the banking industry and to M&T Bank Corporation. M&T encourages participants to refer to our SEC filings, including those found on Forms 8-K, 10-K and 10-Q, for a complete discussion of forward-looking statements.
Now I’d like to introduce our Chief Financial Officer, René Jones.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don, and welcome, everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call today. I believe we’re the last call this morning among our regional and superregional peers, so when we're finished, you can settle down and try to assess what it all means. I'
componenttext:
Thank you, Don, and welcome, everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call today. I believe we’re the last call this morning among our regional and superregional peers, so when we're finished, you can settle down and try to assess what it all means. I'd like to cover the highlights of the recent quarter, after which I'll take your questions. 
For the third quarter of 2010, diluted earnings per common share were $1.48, up from $1.46 in the previous quarter and $0.97 in the third quarter of 2009. Net income for the recent quarter was $192 million, up from $189 million in the linked quarter and $128 million in last year's third quarter.
Recall that our GAAP results for the third quarter of '09 included $9 million of after-tax merger-related benefit, arising from a gain on the Bradford Bank acquisition, which was partially offset by merger-related expenses arising from both the Provident and Bradford transactions. There were no merger-related expenses in this year's second quarter or third quarter. 
Our results for the third quarter of 2010 included after-tax expense from the amortization of intangible assets amounting to $8 million or $0.07 per share. This compares to $9 million and $0.07 per common share in the linked quarter and $10 million or $0.09 per common share in the year-ago quarter.
Net operating income, which excludes the amortization of intangibles, as well as the net merger-related benefit in last year's third quarter, was $200 million for the recent quarter, up from $198 million in the linked quarter and $129 million in last year's third quarter. Diluted net operating income per share was $1.55 for the third quarter of 2010, up from $1.53 per share in the prior quarter and up 58% from the $0.98 per share in last year's third quarter. In accordance with SEC guidelines, this morning's press release contained a tabular reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP results, including tangible assets and equity.
Turning to the balance sheet and income statement. Taxable equivalent net interest income was $576 million for the third quarter, up from $573 million in the linked quarter and up 4% from $553 million in the third quarter of 2009. The net interest margin expanded slightly during the third quarter, rising to 3.87% from 3.84% in the second quarter of 2010 and was up 26 basis points from the 3.61% in last year's third quarter.
The yield on earnings assets was up about 2 basis points during the quarter, primarily reflecting favorable loan repricing. We also realized the benefit of prepayment penalties and the recognition of cash interest payments on non-accruing loans that was comparable to the levels that we saw in the second quarter. The cost of funds declined by 1 basis point, reflecting the benefit of a shift in mix of core deposits from time deposits to non-maturity savings product.
Looking forward, we seem to be on track with our previous comments back in January, that our full year margin would not likely be higher than 3.80% through 3.85%. Through the first 9 months of 2010, the margin was 3.83%.
As for the balance sheet. Average earnings assets declined by an annualized 5% as compared to the second quarter of 2010, and this included the impact from a $382 million decrease in investment securities and a $443 million or 3% annualized decline in average loan balances. On an end-of-period basis, total loans for this year's third quarter declined by $270 million or 2% annualized from the end of period of the prior quarter. On the same basis by category, C&I loans declined by $229 million or 7% annualized. Commercial real estate loans declined by $33 million or 1%. Consumer loans also declined by $33 million or 1%, while residential real estate loans grew by $25 million or 2%. 
Despite the overall pressure on loan volumes, we've seen a few encouraging signs. On an end-of-period basis, the pace of decline in total loans has slowed from rates seen in each of this year's first and second quarters. In the final month of the quarter, we saw a growth in commercial and industrial loans and stable commercial real estate loans. Finally, much of the quarterly decline appeared to be driven by lower utilization rates as overall commitments rose.
Turning to non-interest income, non-interest income was $290 million for the recent quarter, up from $274 million in the linked quarter, and the recent quarter's results included $8 million of securities losses compared with $22 million in the prior quarter. Mortgage banking fees were $61 million for the third quarter compared with $47 million in the linked quarter.
Origination volumes were 29 million -- excuse me. Origination volumes were up 29% during the recent quarter, reflecting in part the record low interest rates, while gain on sale margins widened further from this year's second quarter. Service charges on deposit accounts were $118 million during the recent quarter compared with $129 million in the linked quarter. The 9% decline was attributable to the implementation of the new Regulation E. The customer response to the new regulation has been consistent with or perhaps slightly better than our expectations. Our decision not to charge NSF fees on transactions less than $10 has had a negative impact on overall fees but has met with a favorable response from our customers.
Turning to expenses. Operating expenses, which exclude the amortization of intangible assets, were $467 million compared with $461 million in the linked quarter. This year's third quarter results included a $3 million addition to the impairment allowance for capitalized mortgage servicing rights. Compared with the $2 million addition in the allowance in the second quarter, last year's third quarter results included no adjustment to the impairment allowance.
The efficiency ratio, which excludes securities gains and losses, as well as intangible amortization, was 53.4% in the third quarter, up just slightly from the 53.1% in the linked quarter.
Next, let's turn to credit. Overall, credit trends remained stable with the linked quarter and considerably improved from the prior year. Criticized and classified loans declined for the fourth consecutive quarter. Non-accrual loans were $1.1 billion or 2.16% of loans at the end of the recent quarter compared with $1.09 billion or 2.13% of loans at the end of the previous quarter. 
Foreclosed assets were unchanged from the previous quarter at quarter end at $193 million. The nonperforming asset ratio, which is nonperforming assets divided by total loans plus real estate and other foreclosed assets, was 2.53% as of September 30, 2010, compared with 2.50% at June 30.
Annualized net charge-offs as a percentage of loans were 73 basis points in the third quarter compared with 64 basis points in the linked quarter. For the 9 months ended September 30, annualized net charge-offs were 70 basis points, down from 100 basis points in the year earlier period.
Net charge-offs for commercial and industrial loans were $33 million in the linked quarter compared with $9 million -- in the third quarter compared with $9 million in the linked quarter. Net charge offs for residential builder construction loans were $11 million for the recent quarter compared with $17 million in the prior quarter.
Net charge-offs for all other commercial real estate loans were $7 million, down from $19 million in the second quarter. Net charge-offs in residential real estate loans were $17 million in the third quarter compared to $13 million in the linked quarter, and net charge-offs on consumer loans were $25 million in the third quarter compared to $24 million in the linked quarter.
The provision for credit losses was $93 million in the third quarter compared with $85 million in the linked quarter. The allowance for loan losses was unchanged at $895 million at the end of the third quarter. The ratio of allowance to credit losses to legacy M&T loans, which excludes acquired loans that were marked to fair value at the acquisition, was also unchanged at 1.86% as compared to June 30. The loan loss allowance as of September 30 was 2.4x annual net charge-offs for the recent quarter and 2.5x annualized net charge-offs year-to-date.
We disclosed loans past due 90 days but still accruing separately from non-accrual loans because they are deemed to be well secured and in the process of collection, which is to say that there is a minimal risk of principal loss. In our case, that's particularly true. Loans 90 days past due were $215 million at the end of the recent quarter. Of these, $194 million or 90% are guaranteed by government-related entities. Those figures were $203 million and $188 million, respectively, at the end of June.
M&T's tangible common equity ratio was 5.96% at the end of the third quarter, an increase of 21 basis points from 5.75% at the end of June. The Tier 1 common ratio was an estimated 6.4% as of the end of the recent quarter, improved from 6.15% at the end of the second quarter.
Turning to our outlook. M&T's credit trends continue to compare favorably with those of the industry overall, and we're seeing signs that the economy continues to stabilize, although unemployment remains high. The decline in loan volumes has continued to moderate, and we expect that trend to continue but at a slow pace.
Late in the third quarter, we began to retain conforming mortgages originated through our retail network to hold on the balance sheet. With the run-off in our securities book, our level of asset sensitivity has been getting a little higher than we like. We believe that it makes more sense in the current environment to retain our own production of mortgage loans rather than to sell them and simultaneously purchase securities from others. For the near term, this action will reduce our residential gain on sale revenues, which ultimately will be offset by higher net interest income in subsequent periods.
We're also thinking through the best approach to collateralize seasonal inflows of government deposits. And to the extent that we choose to use repurchase agreements, we'd expect a modest benefit to net interest income in the future and a reduction of net -- in the net interest margin by a few basis points.
Finally, 2 weeks ago, Allied Irish Banks took their initial steps to divest their shareholdings in M&T that they've held since we bought Allfirst Financial from them in 2003. In doing so, they sold 26.7 million notes convertible into 26.7 million shares of M&T stock following the approval by AIB shareholders. The notes were priced at $77.50 each, valuing them at 2.5x our June 30 tangible book value, and 20.2 million of those notes were sold to 123 institutional investors. Some 6.5 million of the notes were sold through the retail channel. We believe the successful completion of this offering demonstrates the strength of M&T's access to the capital markets.
In closing, I would remind you that all of our projections are subject to a number of uncertainties and various assumptions regarding national and regional economic growth, changes in interest rates, political events and other macroeconomic factors which may differ materially from what actually unfolds in the future. We'll now open up the call to questions, before which Paula will briefly review the instructions.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Bob Ramsey of FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Bob Ramsey of FBR Capital Markets.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's interesting that you mentioned you all are beginning to portfolio conforming mortgages. I know, historically, you felt that the return on capital on those assets didn't justify having a big portfolio. Could you just maybe expand a little bit
componenttext: I think it's interesting that you mentioned you all are beginning to portfolio conforming mortgages. I know, historically, you felt that the return on capital on those assets didn't justify having a big portfolio. Could you just maybe expand a little bit on the change, particularly with mortgage rates as low as they are, and also talk about, are these ARMs? Are they fixed-rate mortgages? Or what is sort of the focus?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that -- that's a good way to start off, Bob. I think that we don't have a difference in change. We've not changed our thinking. We still have the same view of what the returns generally are on residential mortgage, given the role -- especially giv
componenttext: I think that -- that's a good way to start off, Bob. I think that we don't have a difference in change. We've not changed our thinking. We still have the same view of what the returns generally are on residential mortgage, given the role -- especially given the role of Freddie and Fannie, but having said that, we long sort of viewed residential mortgage as substitutes for securities. They have the same profile, and we lump them all into our discretionary portfolio. So what is unusual today is that there's a big difference in both rates and yields and returns that you can get on mortgages and securities today. And so if you start thinking about it, it really doesn't make sense for us to be selling assets at the same time we're buying them because we're basically just giving up the transaction spread. So economically, the best thing to sort of do to balance out your portfolio is to just slow down the amount that you're selling, and it sort of helps keep ourselves neutral. So it's the cheapest way to keep the balance sheet where we'd like it.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. That helps. And then could you also maybe talk a little bit about your plans for your trust preferreds as Basel III and U.S. capital rules are slowly getting a little bit clearer. I know they're largely callable. Do you all anticipate calling them a
componenttext: Okay. That helps. And then could you also maybe talk a little bit about your plans for your trust preferreds as Basel III and U.S. capital rules are slowly getting a little bit clearer. I know they're largely callable. Do you all anticipate calling them at some point? And if so, how would that funding be replaced, and what might be the impact on funding cost?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well -- okay. So you've got a 2-part question in a sense. The first part is a big chunk of them, $450 million or so, just are cheap debt. I mean they're priced so low that we would never sort of call them. We would retain them. And then the second part of
componenttext: Well -- okay. So you've got a 2-part question in a sense. The first part is a big chunk of them, $450 million or so, just are cheap debt. I mean they're priced so low that we would never sort of call them. We would retain them. And then the second part of that, second half of it is, your question is, sort of what happens with capital, and as you know, we really won't find out probably for another 6 months exactly what the rules will be around that. So I realize that they'll probably lose their capital content, but I guess the big question really is what is the sort of -- what are all the rules around risk-weighting. And when you think of M&T, if you were to sort of stack up our capital structure versus everybody else, much more of our Tier 1 risk-weighted capital or let's say Tier 1 common equity is just dependent upon common equity, right, so we've never -- what our likely thinking is going to be to think about the risk-weighting of our balance sheet. And in our minds, is the risk-weighting today appropriate, or do we need to have a different one, which would basically mean maybe you'd hold more residential mortgages or some other types of securities slightly? In terms of what we do with the rest of it, it depends on what the rules are, but it's all callable, so we would take it out if it was necessary. But I don't think you still have enough information around what the exact rules are going to be to make that decision today.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from John Pancari of Evercore Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from John Pancari of Evercore Partners.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: René, could you talk a little bit more about your loan growth outlook, specifically the trends that you saw in September? It's interesting that you actually saw some C&I growth and stabilization in CRE. Is that something you think could continue, given t
componenttext: René, could you talk a little bit more about your loan growth outlook, specifically the trends that you saw in September? It's interesting that you actually saw some C&I growth and stabilization in CRE. Is that something you think could continue, given the stabilization in the utilization rates?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that if I go back to where we were in January, what we were talking about is that we had planned to have a certain amount of loan growth for the year, and we didn't expect to see much in the first half, but we thought it would turn around by the s
componenttext: I think that if I go back to where we were in January, what we were talking about is that we had planned to have a certain amount of loan growth for the year, and we didn't expect to see much in the first half, but we thought it would turn around by the second. I think all of that is happening. It's just happening at a much slower pace. So that's why I mentioned the fact that if you look at first, to second, second to third, and then now, this last quarter, you see a moderation in the decline. The other thing that I think is relatively encouraging is that when we look at this quarter's decline, almost all of it on the commercial side is lower utilization, and I think what you're seeing, if we kind of work our way across the commercial bank, we've seen, for example, in the mid-Atlantic, a number of customers who are paying down debt, repositioning themselves. We've seen in the commercial real estate space a number of pretty well-healed commercial real estate folks actually just looking at the liquidity in their portfolio and maybe selling down some projects to improve the overall liquidity position. But overall, our commitments are up. So I think people are just on hold. The rates are low. They're trying to lock in some credit today, but they're not necessarily using it because they're not yet investing. And I would guess that the trends will continue to improve, but I wouldn't expect a big spike up in loan growth all of a sudden. The other thing I would point out is that in the volume of loans that went through our senior loan committee, they were higher than last quarter, and the returns were better.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. On the NPLs, just -- you saw them go up in the quarter despite the increase in charge-offs. I know you indicated that the watch list improved, but can you talk a little bit about the inflows into nonperformers this quarter and what t
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. On the NPLs, just -- you saw them go up in the quarter despite the increase in charge-offs. I know you indicated that the watch list improved, but can you talk a little bit about the inflows into nonperformers this quarter and what that may mean in the coming quarters?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the increase was up $9 million. And I think what's most interesting to me is that in that $9 million increase, there was a $27 million increase in construction and development. And of that $27 million increase in construction and development, $15
componenttext: Yes. So the increase was up $9 million. And I think what's most interesting to me is that in that $9 million increase, there was a $27 million increase in construction and development. And of that $27 million increase in construction and development, $15 million came from the Provident loans in the mark-to-market, right, so you're not going to see a lot of loss content coming from that. The continued positive trend was that C&I was down $33 million, all right? So when we look at construction and development, either this is a portfolio that we've marked before or a portfolio that we've sort of taken -- we reserved for on the balance sheet. And so there are really no surprises there. So I think as Don has been saying for some time, you're just going to get some lumpiness as we move our way and things improve. It will take some time, and this is one of the quarters where we saw some more of the C&D actually fall from the classified book into nonperforming.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Craig Siegenthaler of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question is from Craig Siegenthaler of Crédit Suisse.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: How should we think about the loan-to-deposit ratio trending here, especially with your comments on holding more resi mortgage loans, but maybe with the mix shift from deposit growth to collateralized deposits, which really get excluded from this math?
componenttext: How should we think about the loan-to-deposit ratio trending here, especially with your comments on holding more resi mortgage loans, but maybe with the mix shift from deposit growth to collateralized deposits, which really get excluded from this math?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, loan deposit-to-ratio is a proxy. It's all about liquidity, and really, we're using the resis to replace the run-off in the securities book. So on the profile basis, it doesn't change it very much. I will say that you've seen -- if you look a
componenttext: Yes. I mean, loan deposit-to-ratio is a proxy. It's all about liquidity, and really, we're using the resis to replace the run-off in the securities book. So on the profile basis, it doesn't change it very much. I will say that you've seen -- if you look at the numbers, I think our deposit growth was flat, but what that's really driven by is -- I’m going to sort of guess [ph], over $450 million. In that was over $450 million of a decline in government deposits from the second to the third. And what you'll see going into the fourth is that they seasonally spike back up. Right? So I think there's not been much change. The deposit growth is slower than we've seen in past -- in the past, and that probably is just consistent with the idea that the thaw -- the slow lending environment is sort of thawing out a little bit as well, but there's not a lot of a renews there.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just can you remind us on the liquidity side, you've been building a little bit of excess liquidity here with the stronger deposit growth. Is your plans to deploy that and help offset declines in NIM driven from security pricing here?
componenttext: And then just can you remind us on the liquidity side, you've been building a little bit of excess liquidity here with the stronger deposit growth. Is your plans to deploy that and help offset declines in NIM driven from security pricing here?

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We said in the script, we talked about this idea of putting on repos to collateralize our government deposits. I mean, if you wanted to make a little more money and do that, you'd put on securities, but I think we're a little cautious because we think tha
componenttext: We said in the script, we talked about this idea of putting on repos to collateralize our government deposits. I mean, if you wanted to make a little more money and do that, you'd put on securities, but I think we're a little cautious because we think that the prices of securities are artificially inflated today, based on the government buying and all the news out there. So really what we're doing is nothing, and we're sort of holding our options open. But you're right. We would have room if we wanted to sort of -- wanted the balance sheet to be a little bit bigger and we could make a little bit more money, but I think we're still a little cautious and uncertain.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Steven Alexopoulos of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next question comes from Steven Alexopoulos of JPMorgan.

headline: M&T Bank Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
